problems.name: Tires on 767 cars
problems.text:
Write a program that prints the number of tires on 767 cars. For this exercise let's assume that all cars have 4 tires.

To arrive at this result, we will have to create an expression that starts with the number of cars and multiples it by the number of tires on each car.

problems.name: Board length
problems.text:
Write a program that prints the length (in feet) of each part of a 10 foot board that is sawn into 7 equal parts ( 10 divided by 7 ).

As we have been doing, we must write an expression that will evaluate to the result we need, and we will put that expression inside the parentheses of an alert statement to get it evaluated and printed out. In this problem, the expression involves number data.

problems.name: Space craft
problems.text:
Write a program that prints the words "space" and "craft" with a hyphen between.

Use string concatenation to do this. Concatenation of strings is done with the + operator. As before, we will create an expression to put inside the the parentheses of an alert statement to get it evaluated and printed. The expression will concatenate the 3 strings together.

problems.name: Quadratic equation
problems.text:
Write a program that prints out the roots of the quadratic equation for the specific case of a:2, b:10, and c:-100. Do this with two separate alert statements, each printing a single number.

Roots of the quadratic equations are computed with these expressions: 


 -b  +/-  square root of ( b^2 - 4ac )  
---------------------------------------------
                      2a
the +/- means do one computation with + and then another with -. Square roots can be computed with the Math.sqrt function. This complicated expression will show you the value of using parentheses to make your intentions unambiguous.

Alert the "+" root first, then alert the "-" root with a separate alert statement.

problems.name: Prof name
problems.text:
Write a program that creates a variable "profName". Then assign my name to it, and print out the value of the variable. For reference, my name is spelled Stotts .

This program will be very similar to the previous one. The difference is we are here storing string data into the variable (rather than number data). Any type of data can be stored in a JavaScript variable. You can, for example, store a number into a variable and then later in the program execution store a string or a boolean into the same variable.

problems.name: Age in months
problems.text:
Write this program by modifying your previous program. Using the variable "profAge" you made earlier, print out how many months old I am. All we need to see is the number of months.

This program will show that more complicated expressions can contain variable names as well at constant data values. In your program, you will create an expression in your alert statement where you multiply by 12 the value stored in variable profAge. To evaluate the expression, JavaScript will retrieve the data stored in "profAge" first, then combine that data with the 12 using the multiplication operator.

Remember that you can reload your previous program by clicking on the previous problem, and clicking the "Reload Last" dark blue button above the editor window.

problems.name: Statement of age
problems.text:
Build this program by modifying the previous one. Use the variable "profAge" , and the computation of my age in months, and this time add an explanatory message to the output along with the number.

The format for the output is this: 

  My prof is 348 months old.
Note the blanks before and after the 348, and the period at the end. You will also produce the printed sentence by using the variable profAge and multiplying it in the alert. In other words, you will compute 348 (as in the previous problem) in order to have that value appear in output.

problems.name: Area of a circle
problems.text:
Write a program that will compute the area of a circle with radius 5.25 units. Print out the result in the format show below.

In your program, first create a variable "pi" and assign to it the value of pi to 5 decimal places (3.14159). Create another variable named "radius" and assign to it the value 5.25. Now using variables "pi" and "radius" compute the area of a circle and assign that to a new variable "area" ( area is pi * radius * radius ).

In this program, we learn how to mix variables with strings using concatenation to make readable and explanatory output. You must print out the value "area" embedded in a message explaining it. The final output will look this way: 

  Area of a circle with radius 5.25 units is 86.590074375 units squared
with no period at the end. The numbers in the output must be computed by expressions using the variables.

problems.name: DIY: Circumference of a circle
problems.text:
Write a program that will compute the circumference of a circle with radius 5.25 units. Print out the result in the format show below.

The formula for circumference is pi * radius * 2 . For pi use 3.14159. You can build this program by modifying the Area of a circle program.

The output should look like this: 

  A circle with radius 5.25 units has a circumference that is 32.986695 units.

problems.name: Quadratic equation 2
problems.text:
Write a program that prints out the roots of the quadratic equation for the specific case of a:2, b:10, and c:-100. Do this with two separate alert statements, each printing a single number.

Let's revisit the quadratic equation, but this time use variables to make the code easier to write and to understand. Start with the program you wrote for the Quadratic equation problem in the Expressions module.

Declare variables "a", "b", and "c". Give a the value 2, b the value 10, and c the value -100. Compute the two roots of the quadratic equation but use the variable names a, b, and c in the expressions. Assign one root to a variable "root1"; assign the other root to the variable "root2". Print out the two root variables using two separate alert statements. Print the "+" root first, and then print the "-" root.

For reference, the roots of the quadratic equations are -b +/- square root of ( b^2 - 4ac ) all over 2a , and you can use Math.sqrt() to compute the square root.

problems.name: DIY: Wheels
problems.text:
A parking lot has 53 cars in it (each with 4 wheels) and 17 trucks (each with 6 wheels). Write a program that prints out the total number of wheels in that parking lot.

Use a single alert statement with an expression to produce the correct number by multiplying and adding appropriately.

problems.name: DIY: Cake
problems.text:
A chocolate cake weighs 7 pounds. It is cut into 13 equal pieces. Write a program that will print out the weight (in pounds) of 3 pieces of cake.

Use a single alert statement to do this, and use an expression to compute the correct number by diving and multiplying appropriately.

problems.name: DIY: Pythagoras
problems.text:
Write a program that will print out the length of the hypotenuse of a right triangle with side lengths 3 and 7.
Use a single alert statement and write an expression that computes the correct number by multiplying, adding, and square rooting appropriately.

The Pythagorean theorem is used (among other things) to compute the length of the hypotenuse of a right triangle, given the lengths of its two shorter sides. The equation is 

   a^2 + b^2 = h^2 

      where h is the hypotenuse.  If we do a little algebra, we get 

   h = square root of ( a^2 + b^2 )

Like we did in the Quadratic equation program, use Math.sqrt ( ) to find the square root.

problems.name: DIY: Gallons and ounces
problems.text:
Write a program that computes the number of ounces in 3.14 gallons.

To get the result, we will produce an expression and save the evaluated value in a variable; we will use the facts that a gallon has 4 quarts, a quart has 32 ounces. Print out the results in a phrase (string) like this: 

In 3.14 gallons there are 401.92 ounces
(with no period at the end, and no blanks before the first "In" and no blanks after the ending "ces"). You will use string concatenation ( + ) to glue all the text strings and number expressions together inside an alert statement.

problems.name: DIY: Easy as 1,2,3
problems.text:
Write a program that takes the string "one" the string "two" and the string "three" and prints out all of them concatenated with commas between.

Use the "+" string operator to do this. The result will be the string "one,two,three" .

problems.name: Overview
problems.text:
Comparisons

Now we return to study Boolean data in more detail. One of the main uses for Boolean (true, false) data is to answer questions like "is the value in this variable larger than the value stored in this other variable?". If we can get answers to questions like this we can make decisions that affect the control flow of our programs, and the final outcomes of them.

We ask questions like this using comparison operators (less than, equal to, greater than, etc.). An expression using comparison operators will "answer" the question by producing a boolean result (true, or false).

To complete this problem, type in this JavaScript program:
    alert( 100 < 200 );
    alert( 100 === 200 );
There are several ways you can interpret a boolean expression. Consider the first expression here... 100 < 200. We are in some sense stating "100 is less than 200" and asking "is this true? or is it false?". Or, you may prefer to think of it as asking a question and wanting a YES or NO answer: "is 100 less than 200" ? Here, we expect YES (or true).

So we expect the first expression to evaluate to true, since 100 is less than 200. We expect the second expression to evaluate to false, since it is not the case that 100 is the same numerical value as 200.

Remember to use the myMain function format for style points.

problems.name: DIY: Pythagoras 2
problems.text:
Write a program that will print out the length of the hypotenuse of a right triangle with side lengths 3 and 7.

In this problem we revisit the Pythagorean theorem: a^2 + b^2 = h^2. As before we need to compute the square root of the sum of the squares of the shorter sides of an right triangle. This time we will declare three variables a, b, and c. Assign the value 3 to a; assign the value 7 to b. Then write an expression using variables a and b that will produce the length of the hypotenuse and assign that value to h. Print out the value of h (just the number).

We need a single alert statement, and that statement will simply print the value of the variable h after you have computed and stored into h the proper result.

problems.name: Overview
problems.text:
Repetition: Loops

Loops give us major problem solving power. Without them programs would be useful for solving only small problems, like we have been doing. Loops allow us to write a finite number of statements but to have them executed many many (possibly infinite) times, by repeating at run-time rather than at write-time.

A "for loop" is designed to be used when we know we need to repeat a block of statements a specific number of times. We call this definite looping; we know when we write the code how many times to repeat. We designate the code block to repeat, and we specify a variable to count the repetitions (called the loop index); we give that variable a starting value (often 0); we write a boolean comparison expression to answer the question "do we repeat again?", and we write an expression telling how to change the value of the index at the end of each repetition (often increment by 1).
To complete this problem, type in this JavaScript program (in proper myMain format): 

  for ( var i=0;  i<3;  i++ ) { 
    alert("the loop body runs"); 
  }

How many times will the alert statement get executed?

problems.name: Accumulator: Sum of nums
problems.text:
Write a program that will print out the sum of the integers from 1 to 99, including 1 and 99.

We will use a for loop to do this. You will also need an "accumulator", a variable that has its value bumped up each time you go through the loop body. Since we are summing, the accumulator will be initialized to 0 (the additive identity) outside the loop. With a counter, the variable is bumped by some fixed amount (often 1). With an accumulator, the variable is bumped up by perhaps different amounts each time it is increased. Think of an accumulator as a bucket. We will accumulate a final value by adding into the bucket parts of the final amount, many times.

Lesson here: the loop index is a variable that can be used inside the loop body; it is often used to generate a sequence of numbers, or to count how many times the loop body has run.

Style: Use one for loop and no other loops.

problems.name: Sequence of numbers
problems.text:
Write a program that will print out the first 5 positive integers (one per alert).

To do this we set up a for loop and use the loop index as a variable that will contain the numbers in this sequence successively as we repeat the loop body. This means one good use for a for loop is to generate a sequence of numbers.

Start the loop index at 1, end it when we have done the 5th body execution; we bump up the value of the loop index by 1 each time we loop. Inside the loop body we simply alert the value of the loop index variable. Since we start the index at 1, the first time the body executes we will get the 1 in the number sequence. Since we increment the index by one, we will get a 2 the next time we do the loop body... and then 3, ... and so on.

The lesson we want to learn in this program is: the loop index (the loop control variable) is a variable like any other in your program, and it's value can be accessed inside the loop body. This is a very helpful feature for solving problems.

Style: Use one for loop and no other loops.

problems.name: Sum of odds
problems.text:
Compute and print out the sum of all the odd integers from 17 to 204.

Use only one for loop and no other loops.

The lesson in this program is that the for loop index variable does not always have to be incremented by 1. If we want to increment it by 2, or 5, or 10, or whatever we can specify that in the loop control information. To generate odd numbers, then, we could start the loop index at 1, and increment it by 2 each time the loop body executes. This would create the sequence of values 1, 3, 5, 7, 9, etc. in the loop index variable.

problems.name: Product of evens
problems.text:
Compute and print out the product of all the even integers from 4 to 16.

Use one for loop and no other loops.

The lesson we are learning in this program is that an accumulator can accumulate by multiplication also. The previous accumulator was being increased by addition, so we started it with the value of 0. In this program, since we will be accumulating by multiplying we will initialize the accumulator variable to 1 (the multiplicative identity for numbers).

problems.name: DIY: Loop index as counter
problems.text:
Write a program that will prompt the user for a positive integer, and then produce output that looks like this: 

body: 0
body: 1
body: 2
 . . .
body: N-1
where N is the number the user gave.

For example, if the user gives number 4 as input, then the program produces 4 lines of output, with the lines numbered 0 through 3.

It's no secret you will do this with a for loop. Each time the body executes it will print out (alert) the message "body: " followed by the appropriate integer. You should use the loop index variable as your body execution counter. The main issue is to get the start/stop/increment loop parameters set up to count properly.

Style: Use one for loop, and no other loops.

problems.name: DIY: Truncated square roots
problems.text:
Write a program that will print the square root of each integer between 99 and 104 (inclusive). Print the square roots truncated to 3 decimal places.

Use one for loop and no other loops. Output should be only numbers (no string data explaining the numbers). Print one square root per alert statement, so your output will be 6 numbers, one per alert.

problems.name: DIY: Powers of 2
problems.text:
Write a program that will print the first 10 powers of 2, starting with 2^1.

Do not use the Math.pow function. Instead, use the loop index tp count body executions (you will do 10 of those), and use an accumulator to build the powers you need at each step. We can start the accumulator at 2 (2^1). After printing the value in the accumulator in the loop body, we double the value stored in the accumulator (we multiply it's value by 2). When we are done, the accumulator will have accumulated the value 2^10, but along the way in each loop iteration it will have accumulated 2^1, 2^2, 2^3, ... 2^i (for the ith iteration), etc.

Another way to do this is use the loop index as an accumulator, but this is a bit more obscure. Start the loop index at 2, and then when it is time to increment the index, instead of the common i++ (increment by 1) we can double the loop index ( i *= 2 ). The lesson here is that the loop index does not have to be incremented by 1... it can be changed in any way you need it to be. So loop index starts at 2 (and gets printed). It then becomes 2*2, and then (2*2)*2... and so forth. Doing the problem this way, the loop has to end when it goes past 2^10.

By the way, 2^10 is 1024. This is the value we means in "computer speak" when we say 1K. The K means roughly 1000, but really is 2 to the 10th power. We do everything in binary (base 2).

Output: Your output should be numbers only, no string data explaining the numbers. You will have 10 numbers, one per alert.

Style: Use one for loop and no other loops.

problems.name: Overview
problems.text:
Repetition: While Loops

A second type of loop statement in JavaScript is the while loop. A while loop is less rigidly structured than a for loop; in a while loop we have to manually set up and maintain any loop index variables, counters, etc. we might need as part of the code in the loop body. We use while loops primarily for what we call indefinite looping, where we do not know (when we write the code) how many times the loop body will need to execute.

It should be noted that these loop forms (for, while) are notational conveniences. We use for loops primarily for definite looping, and we use while loops primarily for indefinite looping; the syntax of each is set up to help create these patterns easily. However, computationally they are equivalent in their capabilities. Anything we can do with a for loop, we can do with a while loop as well, and vice versa. This means we can do definite loops with while ( but a for loop would be more convenient ). We can also do indefinite looping with a for loop (but a while would be easier). It is a bit more common to use a while loop for definite looping than it is to use a for loop for indefinite. We will see this in the problems in this folder.

As with for loops we will write a boolean comparison expression to answer the question "should we execute the loop body another time?" ; this expression will usually examine the variables being used in the loop body.

To complete this problem, type in this JavaScript program (remember to use the myMain function format for style points): 

  var x = 1; // loop index varible
  while ( x <= 5 ) { 
    alert ( x*x ) ; 
    x = x + 1 ;  // increment the loop index
  }
  alert("while loop is done");
This is a definite loop; it is set up to execute the loop body 5 times. Note that the loop index variable (x) we had to set up and increment ourselves. We started x at 1, and stopped when it became larger than 5. In a for loop, this bookkeeping is done automatically for us. For this while loop, we print the square of the index variable each time we execute the loop body. Thus, the output is a sequence of the squares of the first 5 positive integers.

problems.name: Overview
problems.text:
More about Functions

We now revisit the abstraction called a function. We have been writing and using a simple function ( myMain ) for a week or two now. We have also been using functions that come with JavaScript (Math.sqrt, Math.floor, etc.) since nearly the beginning. We will now learn more about how to write and use function like Math.sqrt() where we pass in some information and get a result back. We wrote one back in module on simple functions (it cubed its parameter and returned it). Now we will practice more.

We will call the functions we write here simple utility functions. They will be handy for asking (and answering) small but useful questions like "is this number an integer" or "is this number odd" in our programs as we progress.

We write a simple utility function in a way very similar to how we are writing myMain. However, since we are passing information in (like we do when we call Math.sqrt(4) for example) for the function to use while computing a result, we will have to specify a parameter. Also, since the point of a utility function is to get some result back, we will need to add a return statement to the body of the function when we define it.

To complete this problem, type in and execute this code: 

"use strict";

function myMain ( ) {
   var x = 5;
   var dubx = double(x);
   alert(dubx);
}

function double ( num ) {
   var val = num*2;
   return val;
}

myMain();
Note that to do these programs with our own functions, we will need to write the myMain( ) function as we have been, and we will also write another function (or several more). These extra functions will be called by the code in the body of myMain.

problems.name: Function isEven ( n )
problems.text:
Write a function called "isEven" that will be passed a number as parameter. If that number is an even integer the function will return true; otherwise the function returns false.

This function is similar in structure and in use to "isInt" that we just wrote. We can also use the mod operator to determine even; remember that is a number is even, it is divisible by 2 with no remainder.

Once you have written and tested isEven, write a myMain function to exercise your isEven function. In myMain write a loop that will ask the user for a number (don't worry about validating the input, just assume the user gives a number). Print the square of the number if it is even. If it is not even, print "nope" and go to the next input. Stop looping when the user gives 0 as input. Make sure that when the user does give a 0, the program stops without printing the square of that 0... in other words, do not treat that 0 as an even number before stopping.

Style:Use one while loop, and no for loops.

Food for thought... how would you do this with a for loop? It seems better to use a while, since we dont know how many times we need to loop before the user gives a 0.

More food for thought... if isEven(n) tells me "false" meaning n is not even, is it odd?

problems.name: DIY: Sum until 1000
problems.text:
Write a program that will add up consecutive integers starting at 1 and print out the integer that causes the sum to go over 1000 when it is added in. Then print out the sum in a second alert statement.

In this program, we are not stopping after a set number of repetitions (like in a for loop) and we are not stopping when the user signals to end. Rather, we will end the loop when some condition on the program data becomes true. In this case, we will watch an accumulator variable (the sum) to see when it's value exceeds some limit (1000).

For example, let's say we wanted to do this problem using 12 rather than 1000 as our sum to watch for. We are going to sum up 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, etc. until our sum becomes larger than 12. 

We start with 1, add it in and get sum of 1 (not larger than 12)
then add 2 to get sum of 3 (not larger than 12)
then add in 3 to get sum of 6 (not larger than 12)
then add in 4 to get sum of 10 (not larger than 12)
then add in 5 to get sum of 15 (... IS larger than 12 so stop summing / looping) 

then print 5 (the number that when added in made the sum go over 12) 
then print 15 (the sum when we stopped).

You must do this with a while loop. You can end the loop with whatever method you prefer. You will need to set up a counter variable to use for generating the sequence of integers that you are summing. You will need an accumulator variable for the sum.

Style: Use a while loop. Use no for loops. There is no user input, so we won't need data validation.

problems.name: DIY: Fizz Buzz
problems.text:
Write a program that will print out the integers from 1 to 20, with these exceptions: if the number is a multiple of 3 print "fizz" instead of the number, if the number is a multiple of 5 print "buzz" instead of the number, if the number is a multiple of both 3 and 5 print "fizzbuzz" instead of the number.

Use a while loop for this program, and do NOT use the "break out" form of ending the loop. Do it with a loop index variable and and condition that tests it for the stopping value. You will also be using the mod (%) operator to determine if a number is a multiple of 3 and/or 5. Don't forget to increment the index variable you are using to control the loop (or you will get an infinite loop).

We could (and most likely would) do this with a for loop (since there is a definite number of repetitions), but we want to practice while loops. So here you will do a definite loop with the while syntax.

Style: Use a while loop. Use no for loops. Do not use the "break" out form of while loop. You will also need some form of conditional statement inside the loop; a cascade might be a good thing to look at (not a switch).

problems.name: Overview
problems.text:
Overview: Encapsulating validation

We will now put our new knowledge of simple functions to work making input validation look cleaner in our programs. The idea is that instead of asking 2 or 3 individual questions (like is this an integer? is this odd? etc.) in our main program when the user gives input, we will put the questions together in the body of a new function named something like "validate". We will pass the input from the user into the validate function as a parameter; the function will return a message indicating what went wrong (or something like "ok" if all went right).

To complete this overview write the following program and run it: 

"use strict";
function myMain() {
   var inp = prompt("input?");
   var result = validate(inp);
   alert(result);
}

function validate ( userInput ) {
   var retVal = userInput + ": OK" ;
   return retVal;
}

myMain();
Now this program is simply declaring all inputs to be OK, but it shows the basic structure we will need.

problems.name: Overview
problems.text:
Scope

"Scope" is the term we use for the parts of a program in which a particular declared variable is visible (useable). "Scope rules" are the decision procedures that allow us to determine what storage location in memory is denoted when we see a variable name in our code. In other words, when you see a variable used in an expression, you can decide which "var" declaration is being used.

It is possible, for example, to have several lines that look like "var x ;" in your code. When we see something like "x = 5 ;" we need to know which of the several "var x ;" lines is the variable being referenced in the expression. In JavaScript we have two main scopes: global, and local.

Global scope is the collection of variables and names (function names) declared outside of all function definitions.
We can have code statements at the global level, and we can have variable declarations at the global level. A global variable can be seen and used inside any function, as well as in code at the global level.

Local scope is the collection of variables and names declared inside a function definition (this includes the parameters).
A local variable can be seen and used by any code that is inside the function it is declared in, but it is invisible (undefined) in code that is global, or inside other function declarations.

We are not going to use global code in most of our programs. For these in this section, where we are specifically learning about global vs. local, we will write and use some.

To complete this overview, type in and run this program: 

"use strict"; 

var gx = 5; // global var declaration

function myMain() {
  alert( gx ); // use of global var from inside local function scope
}

alert(gx);  // use of global var from global scope
myMain();
Here the variable "gx" is in the global scope (we say "gx is a global variable") because it is declared not inside any function. Since it is global, we can use it inside any function. Hence, we can print our its value from inside of myMain. We can also print its value at the global level.

Note also that the name "myMain" is also a global name; this is why the call to myMain is outside any function as well. That call is a global code statement. For most of our programs, that is the only global executable statement we will have. In this code, we have two global executable statements: the alert, and then the call to myMain.

problems.name: Local vs. local
problems.text:
Write a program that shows how locals in one function are not seen in another function.

The local variables in one function cannot be seen or used in another function. Scope rules says resolving a name looks locally in the function where the name is used, and then globally. Use of a name in one function cannot refer to storage created inside another function.

When we need to communicate values from one function to another , we do it with parameter passing (and the return statement).

In this program we will create in myMain a variable "num" and put 5 into it. We will declare a variable "num" at the global lever and put 10 into it. Then write a function "helper" that takes no arguments; helper will print the value of "num" and return. Call helper in myMain. When it runs you will see that in function helper, the "num" in myMain is not seen. Rather, helper see the global "num".

problems.name: Overview
problems.text:
Basic Objects: Structured data

Objects are collections of data with "tags" to identify the components. You can think of an object as a container full of named data items. The components of an object are called its "fields" or "properties". Later we will see that objects can contain functions as well as data, but for now we will think of them as a wrapper around a collection of named data items. Although the data items in an object are called "fields" or "properties" we can also think of them as variables. They will behave like variables... we will be able to store data into them, and retrieve data from them, and use them in expressions.

We will start with object literals. An object literal is a way of specifying an object value directly, like a constant... like 5 is a number literal or "go heels" is a string literal.

To complete this problem type in and run this code: 

"use strict";

function myMain() {
   alert( {a:5, b:"hello"}.a );
   alert( {a:5, b:"hello"}.b );
}

myMain();
Here, the object literal (value) is {a:5, b:"hello"} which contains two fields, tagged "a" and "b". The "dot notation" is used to select a field. Thus, {a:5, b:"hello"}.a says to select the value of the field tagged "a" from the object, and the alert will print 5.

Now type in the following code: 

"use strict";

function myMain() {
  var obj = {a:5, b:"hello"};
  alert( obj.a );
  alert( obj.b );
}

myMain();
If you run this (or submit it for score) you will see that it does the same thing as the first form. In this second form, we create a variable and store the object literal into it (same as doing "var x = 5;" with a number literal). We now see that the dot notation, to select a field from an object, can be used after a variable name also. This second form is by far the more heavily used way to create and access objects.

Even though we saw that objects do have literal values (like the {a:5, b:"hello"} ) there is a difference between a literal object and a literal number data value. A number literal does not have parts, or components; it is unstructured ... it has only one part. In contrast, objects have parts -- they are constructed from components (the fields) and they are organized. They are what we call structured data. We will see that you can used an object as an abstract collection (by referring to the variable containing the object) or you can use a piece of an object... you can access portions of the structure. This is what the dot notation does.

problems.name: Construct person object
problems.text:
Write a program that will created 3 objects to represent 3 different people (employees) and use those objects to compute total pay for each person.

In this program we will see how a function can be used to create and return (manufacture) an object. A function that manufactures objects is called a "constructor".

Write a program that has two functions: myMain (with no arguments) and makePersonObject (with no arguments). In function makePersonObject you will first create an empty object and then query the user for 4 pieces of information: an id number, a name, number of hours worked (allow non-integer) and hourly pay rate (as a positive real number) in that order. No need to validate the user input. The user input values go into 4 fields in the object (with tags id, name, hours, payrate). When it is filled, makePersonObject will return the object.

In myMain call the makePersonObject function 3 times, and each time put the returned object into a new different variable. When that is done, print out the total pay for each person (using a separate alert statement for each person). Do this by accessing the hours fields and payrate fields and doing the math.

problems.name: Average of randoms
problems.text:
Write a program to generate 1,000,000 random numbers between 0 and 100 (include 0, exclude 100) and compute the average. Print the average rounded to the nearest integer.

We want to make sure the random numbers are floating point values (in other words, don't convert the output from the scaled Math.random to integer). We are not converting to integer until after the average is taken. Note that we are rounding the final average for output (not truncating).

For thought: given the uniform distribution, what do you think the average should be for a big pile of random numbers between 0 and 100?

problems.name: Overview
problems.text:
Overview: Random numbers

Random numbers are important mathematically for many problem solutions. Statistical modeling depends on them to simulate the unpredictable behavior seen in physical systems that we study by writing computer programs -- we call such programs "simulations". Programming languages contain the capability to generate random numbers when a program is executing. In JavaScript, we use the function Math.random() to do this.

Math.random will generate and return a single random number between 0 and 1. It might return 0, but it will never return 1. Remember your interval notation from algebra? We write [0-1) for the range of the Math.random function, meaning it produces a number x where 0 <= x < 1 .

Math.random will return a different number every time it is called, but the value will always be in that range. The numbers will be distributed uniformly (evenly) over that range, meaning the probability of getting any particular number with in the [0-1) range is the same as the probability or getting any other particular number.

If you run a program that calls Math.random() many times, and graph the output with something like a bar chart, it will be flat (showing the uniformity)... it will NOT follow some other distribution shape such as a bell curve. If you need a distribution other than uniform, you end up writing a program that uses Math.random but biases the output numbers as you need.

Type the following code into the Bricks editor window and execute it: 

"use strict";

function myMain() {
  var ranNum = Math.random();
  alert(ranNum);
}

myMain();
Run this code several times locally to see how Math.random behaves. Then submit it for score.

problems.name: Alter upper end of range
problems.text:
Write a program that will generate a single random number between 0 and 50 (but never quite being 50) and print it.

Math.random produces numbers in the range [0,1). Here we need numbers in an expanded range [0,50), with the lower end still at 0. We want the distribution to remain uniform. So to do this, we can simply generate a random number and multiply it by a factor that will expand the range upward. The obvious factor (in this case) is 50. All numbers generated by Math.random are then used as a percentage, telling how far into the range [0,50) to go to get the final random output.

Let's reason about the range that results after this scaling. Since Math.random might generate a 0, and since 0*50 is zero, the scaling might also generate 0 (as we wish). Since Math.random with almost (but not quite) generate a 1, the scaling will generate (almost 1)*50, or almost but not quite 50 (as we wish).

One last comment... mathematically, we are talking about numbers with precision after the decimal point here (floating point, or real number values). We are not trying to generate random integers in this program. We will do that in later programs.

problems.name: Random integers (and range change)
problems.text:
Write a program that will generate a single random integer between 0 and 100 (including both) and print it. Then generate a single random integer between 5 and 25 (including both) and print it.

This problem illustrates two new capabilities: generating random integers, and moving the lower range up from 0.

For integers, we will use Math.floor to take a random real number and make it integer. Note the twist here... the integer range is [0,100], meaning we want to include the upper end (100). Since Math.random will never generate exactly 1, if we scale the range by multiplying by 100, we will never quite get 100 and then Math.floor will back that down to the integer 99. So if we want 100 as possible output, we must scale to (almost) 101 and let Math.floor truncate to 100.

For the second output, we note that we need to shift the range up 5 from 0. The high end of the range we want is 25, so if we generate a number between 0 and 20, then add 5 we get a range of 5 to 25. So we can scale the range by multiplying the output of Math.random, and we can shift the range by adding to the result of Math.random (or the result of Math.floor(scaled random).

problems.name: For loops for systematic access
problems.text:
Write a program that will go through an array item-by-item, from the beginning, and print each element.

We will create an array containing the first 10 prime numbers (with 2 being the first prime). Do this with a variable declaration and a array literal to initialize that variable.

Needing to access every element in an array, systemaically, is a very common and heavily used programming pattern. We use a for loop to dom it, as we know the size of the array (we know exactly how many elements we need to access). Inside the for loop body, we handle one element, and we use the loop index variable to designate which array slot number we are dealing with each iteration.

To print the array elements, use a for loop that runs from 0 up to (but not including) the length of the array. This means if the array length is 10, then the for loop runs from 0 to 9. However, we will use the length expression in loop control -- rather than the literal 9, or 10 -- since that is more general. Then in the loop body, we use the loop index variable as the expression in the subscript square brackets to get the value stored in the array slot.

problems.name: Overview
problems.text:
Arrays: Organizing data

Arrays are structured data, meaning a way to organize a collection of data so that the components may be systematically accessed. It also is an abstraction, meaning we can deal with the entire data collection as a unit (as well as access the individual elements in the collection).

We can think of an array as a numbered collection of storage slots. The numbers begin with 0, and go upwards by 1. An array has a name, like a simple variable, and is declared like a variable. But unlike a simple variable, to store or retrieve a data value we must specify the slot number (called the "index"). With an array, we must keep separate the difference between the slot number and the data value stored in that slot. Slot numbers are always integer (type number); the data stored in the array slot itself can be any type (including an object, or even another array as we will see).

Here is an array of cars over at the Carolina Inn. In slot 2 is a silver Volvo. In slot 3 is a white Cadillac. It's not difficult with physical cars to see the difference between the integer 2 (slot number) and a Volvo ("data" stored in the slot). There will be a bit more confusion when we want to store number data in array slots that are numbered. .

We can also think of an array as a row of mail boxes. Each box has a number (address), and contents (the mail). We will have syntax in JavaScript to specify the address, and different syntax to open the box at an address and put in (take out) the mail. To open and use a mailbox (array slot) we put square brackets after the array variable name (like " arr[ ... ] " ). To specify an address (slot number) we put an expression that evaluates to an integer inside the square brackets (like " arr[ 5 ] " or " arr[ x+3 ] " ).

Type in and execute this code (it is global code, that's ok here): 

"use strict";

function myMain() {
   var data = [ 7, "smith", -4.25, true ];
   alert(data.length);  
   alert(data[0]);
   alert(data[1]);
   alert(data[2]);
   alert(data[3]);
   alert(data[10-7]);
   alert( data[10 - data[0] ] ) ;
   alert(data[0] * data[2]);
   alert(data[Math.sqrt(4)]);
   var x = 2;
   alert(data[x]);
   var arr = data;  // copies the entire array as a whole
   alert(arr[0]);
}

myMain();
To know how many items are in an array, use the "length" property. For the variable "data" above the expression "data.length" tells how many items are stored in that array (in this case, 4 elements).

To access an array element we use an expression inside "[" "]" square brackets. The expression must evaluate to a non-negative integer. In this example we use mostly integer literals; in future programs we will use variable names, as well as more complex expressions like 2*x +1, etc.

Also, arrays subscripts (slots numbers) always begin with 0. This creates a bit of confusion until you are used to it, since the first element in the array is at slot 0. An array with 2 items in it will use subscripts 0 and 1. Just pay attention when you write code and think carefully about the expressions you use for subscripts. In the example above, we see that arr has 4 elements and uses slot numbers 0 through 3.

problems.name: Average of primes
problems.text:
Write a program that will print out the average of the first 10 primes (with 2 as first prime).

We are going to use an array to do this. As in an earlier problem, we will first create an array that contains the first 10 primes. Then we will systematically access every element in the array, from slot 0 to the last, and sum up all the values stored in the array. This will be the same as an accumulator pattern we have used many times before.

Once we have the sum, and the for loop ends, we compute the average by dividing the sum by the number of elements we summed up. We will use the length of the array to divide (i.e.: we do not simply divide by the constant 10).

problems.name: Even numbers
problems.text:
Write a program that will put the first 1000 positive even numbers into an array, from smallest to largest (let's assume 0 is even and start with that). Print out selected elements when done.

We saw that we can load up an array dynamically with input values given by the user. In this program, we are going to compute values and store them one-by-one into successive array slots. We will use a for loop to do the work, since we know we need to create and store 1000 data values. We will use the loop index variable to tell us what slot number to store the even number into, and the loop index variable will start at 0 and increment by 1 each iteration.

We will need a counter of some sort to generate the even numbers in order, and inside the body of the for loop we will assign the current even number to the current array slot. We will then compute the next even number.

When done, print the first, second, seventh, 200th, and next-to-last elements from the array, one per alert statement.

problems.name: DIY: Random array 2
problems.text:
Write a program that creates an array and puts into it 7 integers randomly generated between 1 and 20 (make sure you can get 1 and 20 both). Use Math.random() to do this, but you will have to manipulate the random numbers it produces to get integers between 1 and 20.

Print out the second element and the 6th element (separate alerts).

problems.name: DIY: Construct athlete objects
problems.text:
Write a program that will call an object constructor to make 3 instances of the athlete object from the last program.

In this program we will see how a function can be used to create and return (manufacture) an object. A function that manufactures objects is called a "constructor".

Write a program that has two functions: myMain (with no arguments) and makeAthleteObject (with no arguments). In function makeAthleteObject you will first create an object from user input as in the previous problem. No need to validate the user input. When the fields of the new object are filled, makeAthleteObject will return the object back to myMain.

In myMain call the makeAthleteObject function 3 times, and each time put the returned object into a new different variable. When that is done, print out the total score for each athlete using the format we used before (see below). Use a separate alert statement for each object. Print each person in the order they were created by the user.

Make the output look like this: 

smith: 45 total points scored in football

Style: Use myMain format. Note that the code from myMain in the last assignment (code that makes the object and gets information from the user for the object fields) can be used as much of the body for the makeAthleteObject function in this program. The myMain in this program will call makeAthleteObject 3 times and save the objects sent back in 3 different variables. You could do this by a for loop that runs 3 times; then in the loop body the object returned from the constructor call is immediately used to compute the points output. However doing it with a loop will not preserve the 3 objects (representing 3 different athletes).

problems.name: DIY: Array fizzbuzz
problems.text:
Arrays: Organizing data

Write a program to do the FizzBuzz problem (a former brick). It is in the while loop section, but this time use a for loop to compute it. Also this time, instead of printing out the numbers and "fizz" etc., put the values into an array. Make an array of 31 items (slots 0 to 30). Let's also just put 0 into slot 0 so we dont have to worry about if 0 is a multiple of 3 or 5. Then go from slot 1 on up and put either the number into the array location (if it is not a multiple of 3 or 5), or put the appropriate "fizz", "buzz", or "fizzbuzz" into the array location.

When done, print out the 4th, 11th, 18th, and last elements (each with a separate alert).

problems.name: DIY: Lookup table
problems.text:
Write a program to create an array that has 1001 slots (index 0 to 1000) . In each array slot store the value of a function (defined following) computed on the number that is the slot number. Using your completed array, print (in separate alerts) the value in slot 8, the value in slot 61, the value in slot 707, and the value in slot 999.

This program is similar to the VID brick we did called "Even numbers". Here we want to be able to store values for 0 to 1000, so the array has to contain 1001 elements (slots 0 to 1000). As we go systematically through the array from slot 0 to slot 1000, for each slot i we compute the function and then store that result into the array at slot i.

The function: For each slot number n, compute n cubed, then take the 4th root of that, and then truncate the result to 10 decimal places. For example, in array slot 5, we will store this: 

trunc10 ( Math.pow( 5*5*5, 0.25 ) )     which is 3.343701524
where trunc10 is a function you write that truncates a number to 10 decimal places. Math.pow ( num, 0.25 ) takes the 4th root (raises num to the 1/4th power), and the 4th root is also the same as taking the square root twice in succession.

This kind of data structure, and usage, is often called a lookup table. The specific function we are computing here (4th root of a number cubed) is not particularly difficult, but some functions can be complicated to compute (expensive in time or memory used) so when we know we will need to compute those values a lot, it can be more efficient to compute a range of them in advance and same the values in an array, where they can be looked up very quickly (more quickly that it would take to re-compute the function). Lookup tables are used in CPU chip in your computer, for example, to make floating point arithmetic faster.

problems.name: Array of objects
problems.text:
Let's build and use an array of objects.

We will start with the code from "Construct person object" from the "Basic Objects" folder. This gives us the myMain function as well as a constructor function "makePersonObject" that manufactures and returns objects after populating them with user input.

In myMain before we created 3 separate variables to store 3 objects. This means the code works for exactly 3 persons, and if the user had more (or less) to work with the code would have to be re-written (a little bit re-written).

In this new program we will make a loop and keep making objects until the user says we are done. Each new object made an returned by the constructor will be stored in an array (in much the same way we have created and used an array to store number input by the user in other programs). In the loop, first call makePersonObject to manufacture a person object; store the object that is returned in the next open array slot. Then ask the user if another object needs to be made. If the reply is "no" then we will break to end the input loop. Any other reply will cause the loop to repeat and make another object.

Once the input loop is done and the array if filled with objects, we will use the objects to compute some information. First, print the length of the array (which is the number of objects stored in the array). Next, compute the total payroll. To do this, go through the array and sum up all the amounts paid to each worker. Print this out with this format: "total payroll: 1234.56"

Then go through the array and find the name of the person with the highest hourly pay rate. Print out the name in this format: "high rate: smith".

problems.name: DIY: makePersonObject 2
problems.text:
Let's modify the previous program "array of objects". We will keep the same basic data and computed results, but we will change the structure of the two functions a bit. We are going to move the user input out of makePersonObject and relocate it to myMain. The values from the user will be passed to makePersonObject as arguments (4 arguments); then in makePersonObject the values of the arguments will be put into the fields when the object is manufactured. As before, makePersonObject will return the new object and in myMain that object will be put into an array.

Output should be the same as before. First, compute the total payroll. To do this, go through the array and sum up all the amounts paid to each worker. Print this out with this format: "total payroll: 1234.56"

Then go through the array and find the name of the person with the highest hourly pay rate. Print out the name in this format: "high rate: smith"

problems.name: Anonymous function (bind to global var)
problems.text:
Write a program that creates a function value that is not bound to a name, and then bind that anonymous function value to a global name.

A function value with no name bound to it is called "anonymous". An anonymous function can still be defined and later bound to a name (saved for later execution). In this problem we illustrate function as first class values by creating a function with no name (an anonymous function) and then "binding" that function value to a name with "=" assignment.

To create an anonymous function value, we use the "function" keyword as we are accustomed to doing, but we do not put a name after the keyword. We do create an argument list (in parentheses) and the code body (in curly braces). It is identical to defining a named function except we do not give it a name. Here is an example (using the code from the previously defined named function "double"): 
function ( n ) {  return 2*n; }
Again, this is a function value... it is the same thing for type "function" as writing the number value "5" is for type "number". It is valid JavaScript, and we must now decide what we wish to do with this value. In this program we will take that function value, and bind it to a global name using assignment. In the next program, we will see how to execute that function value without ever naming it.

Details. First at the global level create an anonymous function value using the previous code for "double" with one argument (as shown in the previous pre-format box). Assign that anonymous function to the global variable "double" using assignment. Then define the global function (myMain) as we usually do. Inside myMain, call double(5) and print the returned result.

Notes. This program illustrates that the "normal" way of defining functions -- using the "function" keyword and a name for the function -- is actually a shorthand notation for doing what we are doing here... creating a nameless function value, and then binding it to a global name. Binding it to a global name is what makes us able to run the function from within our other functions. Also, we must be careful to get our code in the right order. Since we are explicitly creating a global variable (the name for the function) we must do that declaration and binding before we call myMain. If we do not, when myMain runs and tried to call the function bound to the name "double", that global variable will not yet have been declared. So do things in this order:

  1. declare the global variable "double" and assign a function to it
  2. declare function myMain , that calls "double"
  3. call myMain to kick it all off

Relevance to objects. We will be (in the next module) putting functions inside objects (we call them "methods" for historical reasons). To put a function into an object, we will be using this form of definition... creating an anonymous function value and then binding it to a field name inside the object.

problems.name: Anonymous function (execute w/o name)
problems.text:
Write a program that creates a function value that is not bound to a name, and then executes that anonymous function.

In this problem we illustrate function as first class values by creating a function with no name (an anonymous function) and executing it without binding it to a name. This is advanced capability of JavaScript, and we are just doing it here to make you familiar with the fact that is can be done. We will not be using this capability in future program in this course. In professional JavaScript programs, such as code for large websites, this technique is used a great deal. It is also a characteristic of languages that are called "functional languages".

For this program, we wont even need a myMain function. At the global level create an anonymous function value (using the previous code for "double" with one argument). After defining the value, supply an argument of 5 to it and execute it. Print the returned result.

Details. What syntax shall we use to cause a function with no name to execute? And how shall we pass it the argument 5 ? Let's consider how we call a named function. First we write the name, then we put the argument(s) in parentheses after the name. For example, to run the "double" function we did this: 

var result = double ( 5 );
What actually happens in this case is the function value bound to the name "double" is retrieved and executed on the arguments in the parenthesized list.

When we have the function value directly, we have no need to evaluate a name to find it. So we will just write out the value, and put a parenthesized list after the function value. That will make the function value execute on the arguments in the parenthesized list: 

var result = ( function ( n ) { return 2*n; } ) ( 5 ) ;
Then the variable "result" will contain the value returned by the execution of the function on the argument 5; that is, the variable result will contain 10. We can then alert the value stored in "result" .

problems.name: Parsing input strings
problems.text:
In this program we will take a (long) input string and break it apart into several substrings. We call this parsing.

Write a program that will ask the user for an input string (format shown below). Then parse the string into substrings using the character " " (blank) as the separator. Put each substring into a slot in an array. Print out the first substring and the last

To parse a string into substrings we will use the "split" methods (function) that is supplied with JavaScript strings. The split function is passed as a parameter the character to use as separator. It returns an array of strings. The separator character is not put into any substring; it is effectively taken out and the characters after the separator (up to the next separator or end) comprise the substring.

The input from the user will be a standard English sentence, with words separated by blanks. For example: 
Time flies like an arrow
When this is parsed using the " " as separator, you get this array of substrings: 
arr[0]: Time
arr[1]: flies
arr[2]: like
arr[3]: an
arr[4]: arrow
Your program would then print "TIme" and "arrow" as the first and last substrings

problems.name: Parsing input strings 2
problems.text:
Let's take one step beyond the last parsing program. In this one, we first parse the user's input string as we did (using " " as the separator). This gives us an array of substrings.

Now we will parse each substring, further dividing the input into parts. Use the "-" hyphen character as separator this time. This will give you an array of the strings between the hyphen.

For each of the top level parsed strings (the ones separated by blanks) print the first and last hyphen-separated substrings.

Example of the input: 
yesterday-is-history tomorrow-is-a-mystery today-is-a-gift
This will give this array: 
arr[0]: yesterday-is-history
arr[1]: tomorrow-is-a-mystery
arr[2]: today-is-a-gift
When we parse the first line we get this array: 
brr[0]: yesterday
brr[1]: is
brr[2]: history
We print "yesterday" and "history" as the first and last, and go on to parse arr[1], etc.

problems.name: MM 1: object method call
problems.text:
function myMain() {
  var n1 = Number(prompt("number?"));
  var n2 = Number(prompt("number?"));
  var ob = makeObj( n1, n2 );
  var val = ob.mxy();
  alert(val);
}

myMain();

function makeObj (a,b) {
  var ob = {
    x: a,
    y: b,
    mxy: function () { return this.x * this.y ; }
  }
  return ob;
}

problems.name: CG: deck and shuffle
problems.text:
We will write an extended program that has the basic structure for a card game. We will be working on this in class and writing it in pairs if you wish to do so. The starting piece is a representation of a deck of cards and a functions that will shuffle the deck.

A card game (and most any computer game) is a simulation in code of a real structure and behavior. To do this, we need to identify the things in the world we are modeling, and then create a representation of each thing in terms of some JavaScript component. Card games usually have at least these things: card, deck of cards, hand, player. Usually we have some common functions as well: deal cards (to the table, to hands), shuffle the deck, pass card from one player to another, lay card on the table. We will start simple: let's create a card representation, a deck representation, and a way to shuffle the deck.

For starters (we will complicate things later) let's represent a deck of cards as an array with as many slots as there are cards in the deck. Let's also represent a card as an integer between 0 and the size of the deck. For order of the deck, we will use the order of elements in the array. For example, let's consider a deck with 5 cards in it. Initially we can generate an array with 5 elements and we will put one of the integers from 0 to 4 in each slot: 
         +----+----+----+----+----+
array:   | 0  | 1  | 2  | 3  | 4  |  
         +----+----+----+----+----+
slot:      0    1    2    3    4
After shuffling, the deck array might look like this: 
         +----+----+----+----+----+
array:   | 3  | 0  | 4  | 2  | 1  |  
         +----+----+----+----+----+
slot:      0    1    2    3    4

Code: In myMain, first ask the user how many cards to put into the deck. Then create an array to represent the deck, and load up the array with the proper integers in order. Print the deck array to verify that all is well (use an alert on the array variable and the whole thing will appear in one alert box).

Now write a function called shuffle that takes one parameter, a deck array. Shuffle will move the array values around randomly so that the cards get put into a new, random order. Return the array that has been shuffled.

Back in myMain, call the shuffle function and pass in the card deck. When shuffle returns a re-ordered deck array, save that into the deck variable. Then print the entire deck again to verify the shuffled order.

How to shuffle We will use in the shuffle function the Math.random function. The values stored in the array (the "cards") will remain as they are. The location (slot) of each "card" will change randomly. The basic idea is to randomly generate 2 slot numbers and then swap the cards stored in those slots. Do this swap a few thousand times and the deck will be nicely rearranged. Let's use for an example a deck with 52 cards. You will need an expression that will generate a random integer between 0 and 51. Call this twice to get two slots between 0 and 51, then swap those two array elements. We did a swap back in the bubbleUp brick. Use this as a pattern.

To get scored Remove the alerts that print the entire deck array (those were for your personal debugging). Make a deck with 20 cards, and then do the following outputs. Before shuffling: alert the first element of the new deck, then the 7th element, and the finally the 13th element ( 3 separate alerts). After shuffling: alert the first element, then the 7th element, and finally the 13th element ( 3 separate alerts). Make sure you also do exactly 10 swaps in the shuffle function.

problems.name: CG: Object deck and shuffle method
problems.text:
Convert the CG1 program into an object-based design.

The basic idea is to make the card deck an object, and to make the shuffle function a method in the deck object. We will need a constructor function for deck object (let's call it makeDeck) and this constructor will need one parameter... the number of cards to put into the initial deck. The makeDeck function will create the array and fill it with cards in order, as you did in myMain in CG1. The makeDeck constructor will also take your shuffle function and convert it into a function inside the deck object. This means using the "this" keyword appropriately to refer to the card array.

The myMain function is now simpler. Ask the user how many cards in the deck. Call makeDeck and pass that number as a parameter. Capture and save the deck object that is returned. Then alert the cards array in the deck object to see the initial in-order card list ( see "show the deck" below ). Ask the deck object to shuffle itself ( that is, call the shuffle method on the deck, using dot notation like deck.shuffle() ). Then alert the entire card arrray in the deck object to see the shuffled card order.

To show the deck
How will we actually print out the cards in a deck? One idea is to reach into the deck object and just name the card array. While this will work, it is not the best practice. A better practice it to put a "show()" function into the deck object so you can ask a deck to show you the cards. The show function will alert the entire array. We will use the show function to convince ourselves that the array is being randomized as we want.

To get Scored
Comment out the show function calls and do the same output we did in CG1 to get scored. That is, when the deck is newly created alert the first card, the 7th card, and the 13th card in 3 separate alert statements. Then shuffle the deck (making exactly 10 swaps). After the deck is shuffled, print those 3 cards again. Even though it is not best practice, do this by reaching into the object and accessing individual elements in the card array. For example, if your cards array is named "cards" in the deck object, then alert deck.cards[0] etc.

problems.name: MM 2: object method with parameter, local vars
CG: Adding methods to deck object
problems.text:
(6-2pts) Extend the CG2 program with more deck methods.

The deck object currently has a "shuffle" method, a "init" method, and a "show" method. Now let's give the deck more functionality.

(1) Add a "size" method to the deck object. The size method will take no parameters and will return a positive integer (or 0) that tells how many cards are in the deck.

(2) Add a "deal" method (function) to the deck object. The deal method will take one parameter (an integer telling how many cards to deal from the deck); it will return an array containing the cards dealt. Make sure to shorten the deck cards as well. For example, if deal is called with the parameter 5, and if the deck starts with 52 cards, then deal returns an array with the first 5 cards from the deck and the deck itself is shortened to 47 cards. Don't forget to make sure to adjust the number of cards so that the size function still works after a deal.

You may find the "slice" method in arrays useful. Read the documentation online for details. The slice method will return a portion of an array. For example, if you have an array variable "arr" then arr.slice(0,5) will return an array consisting of the elements 0, 1, 2, 3, and 4 from arr. Calling arr.slice(5) will return all elements from 5 to the end.

(3) Add a "getCard" method to the deck object. This method will take one parameter (an integer 1 or greater) and it will return the card that is in that position in the deck. For example, if the getCard method is called with 5, then return the 5th card (which is found in slot 4 in the array in the deck).

To get scored: The myMain function should do the following things. First ask the user how many cards to put in the deck, then make a new deck with that many cards. To get scored, use 52 as the number of cards. Do not shuffle the deck. Call the deal method on the deck and pass it a 5 (deal 5 cards); save the array returned in a variable. Print the first and 5th card in that array (using two separate alerts). Call the deal method again and pass it 7 (deal 7 cards); save the array that it returned in a variable. Print the 2nd and 7th cards from this array (two separate alerts). Then call the size method on the deck, and print the number that is returned. Finally, print the 3rd and last cards remaining in the deck (separate alerts). Use the "getCard" method to retrieve these cards; do not just peek into the array in the deck object (as we have been doing up to now).

problems.name: CG: Adding card objects
problems.text:
Now let's change how cards are represented. We will make alterations to CG3. In CG3 a card is an integer, and the deck object contains an array of these card/integers. In this program we will represent a card with an object. The deck will still have an array to contain all the cards, but each slot in the array will hold a card object.

We will need a constructor to make card objects. We will call this makeCard() and it will take an integer as parameter. This will be stored in the card as the card number. Using this number we will also compute the proper suit and face for the card.

In the deck object the methods deal, shuffle, should still work usefully. We will have to alter the show method.call the makeCard function.

The makeCard function will construct an object with the card number as well as the face and suit. It will also have a show function and a getName function.

myMain will have to be altered to produce card numbers according to the new card structure. To get scored:
The myMain function should do the following things.
  1. First make a new deck with 52. Do not shuffle the deck.
  2. Call the deal method on the deck and pass it a 5 (deal 5 cards); save the array returned in a variable.
  3. Print the first card in that hand array; use the card show method to do this (it's format is "0:2D", the card number, a colon, then the name).
  4. Print the 5th card in that hand array with a call to the card show method.
  5. Call the deal method again and pass it 7 (deal 7 cards); save the array that it returned in a variable.
  6. Print the 2nd and 7th cards from this array (two calls to the card show method).
  7. Then call the size method on the deck, and print the number that is returned.
  8. Finally, print the 3rd and last cards remaining in the deck (separately). Use the "getCard" method to retrieve these cards, and call the show method on the cards returned.

problems.name: Overview
problems.text:
Data
Data is the basic information we use computers to manipulate for us. People and place names, ages, heights, lengths, dollars and cents, time, sentences, all these are information we may wish to have a computer program use. JavaScript provides 3 types of fundamental (basic, simple) data:
  • number
  • string (or text)
  • boolean
Numbers are formed from digits 0-9, the negative symbol (-) and perhaps a decimal point (.) .
Examples include 11, -3.2, 27.12398745, 9.0, -10000, .25, 0.25

Strings are sequences of alphabetic characters, digits, and punctuation characters enclosed in quote marks.
Examples include "hello", "COMP 110", "Welcome to class!", "x", "100", "up/down and side-ways"

Boolean data represent logical truth; there are only two boolean values: true and false . We do not put quotes around true and false, we just use them as special words. The value true is boolean, but the value "true" is a string. In similar fashion, the value 200 is a number, but the value "200" is a string.

We will look at boolean in detail later. In this module, we will practice mostly with numbers and strings.

Output

In order for a computer program to be useful to us, it not only has to manipulate information, if must get that information out to us in a form we can understand and use. This is called output. Programming languages usually offer many ways to get a computer to output information. For JavaScript we will start with the very basic "print something to the screen" function. This is the alert function. The alert function in JavaScript produces a popup box on the screen, with the requested output printed inside the box.

Using the alert function it is our first example of a function call. When we call a function we are asking that the program perform the named activity, and we pass information to the function to use during its activity. To call a function (in this case, the "alert" function) we write its name and in parentheses we write the information we wish to pass in (called parameters, or arguments).

So let's try calling the alert function to get some output. To complete this problem, type the following JavaScript line, run it, and then submit it for credit:

    alert( "data types: number, string, boolean" ) ;

Make sure you pay careful attention to where all the blank characters are inside the quotes, and how many there are. To get this program correct, your quoted string will have to be exactly the same as the one shown there. This sort of detail is very important in programming and it can be very frustrating to you -- the programmer -- as well.

Note that the syntax we use to call a function is based on mathematical notation. We have all seen something like this:
    y = sine(x)
Here the function we are "running" is the trigonometric sine and the information we are passing in is the argument x. The function computes a value based on x and produces it.

The programs that follow will show you examples of the 3 fundamental data types in JavaScript: number, string, and boolean. All data values in our JavaScript programs will be of these types. The programs in this module will show you how data values of each type are formed. We call these individual data values "constants". A constant is a data value that does not change (i.e., its value is fixed... constant).

problems.name: Course name
problems.text:
Write a program that prints (alert) the catalog designation of this course ( "COMP 110" ). For things like names, we use string data. We use the alert function to do output to the screen, so put the data you want to see on the screen inside parentheses like this:

alert( "COMP 110" );

To complete this program, type the JavaScript line above into the editor window, run it locally to test, and then submit it for credit. We put a semicolon at the end as a rule of properly formed JavaScript statements. It's like English grammar requiring a "." at the end of a sentence.

A string can contain just about any keyboard characters inside the quote marks. Here are some valid string values: 
  "hello"    "123"    "542 xyz"    "     "     "quick brown fox"   "Smith's house"  <-- note here the ' inside the string
A string can start with either " or ' and must end with the same style quote mark. This allows us to make string values with the " character inside: 
  'another string'    'ten 10 tin'     'The speaker said "Welcome!!" to the crowd'     '#hashtag'    'go-fight-win!!@gmail.com'
Try printing some of these using local testing.

problems.name: Current year
problems.text:
Write a program that prints (alert) the current year ( 2017 ). Here we use number data, so there will be no quotes around the numeric value 2017.

Data values of type number can be what we called in math class "integer" (no decimal point), or they can be floating point, with a decimal point: 

  123    16.21456    -1976   -98.4381   -500    27.70000001    0     0.01     -0.00004
Floating point numbers are also often called "real" numbers. There are a few other formats for numbers, such as scientific notation, but we will deal with them specifically when we need them.

No matter the format, in JavaScript they are all data values of type "number".

problems.name: Boolean true
problems.text: The boolean value indicating truth or true-ness is the special keyword true . Keywords are not the same as text or string data; we do not put them in quotes to use them. Print out the boolean value indicating true-ness.

problems.name: Slice of Pi
problems.text:
Print (alert) the value of pi truncated to 5 decimal places.  
Truncating is not rounding, it is just chopping.  
Truncating a number to 5 decimal places then is using all of the number to the left of the decimal point, and the first 5 digits to the right of the decimal point and leaving off all the other digits further out to the right.
The value of pi is 3.14159265358979, more or less.

problems.name: DIY: Length of a mile
problems.text: Write a program that prints (alert) the number of feet in a mile.  The output is simply one number, an integer. If this is not something you remember directly, then just Google it up.

problems.name: DIY: Eighth month name
problems.text:
Write a program that prints (alert) the name of the 8th month of the year.  
For those who don't have a calendar, this is spelled August .

problems.name: DIY: Boolean value false
problems.text: The boolean value indicating falsehood is the special keyword false . Keywords are not the same as text or string data; we do not put them in quotes to use them. Print out the boolean value indicating falsehood.

problems.name: DIY: One fourth
problems.text:
Print out (alert) the number that is the decimal representation of the fraction one fourth.  Do not try to get JavaScript to do any division, 
simply have it print out the proper decimal number directly.

problems.name: Overview
problems.text:
Expressions are how we take basic data values and combine them with operations to make new data values. Expressions retrieve data values stored in memory and also use constants (literals).

Operations for numbers include +, -, *, /, and %.

Operations on strings include + (concatenation) and various functions to take portions of a string (substring).

Operations on boolean include && (and), || (or), ! (not), and other functions we will see later.

To complete this problem, type the following JavaScript line and run it: 
     alert(1+1); // number 1 plus number 1

problems.name: Prof age
problems.text:
Write a program that creates a variable named "profAge". Then assign my age to it, and print out the value of the variable.

For reference, I am 29 years old. I have been for a long time :) .

To complete this problem, you will need to declare the variable requested, and assign the appropriate value to that variable. Then in an alert statement, simple type the variable name. Using the name of a variable in an expression is called "referencing the variable". When a variable is referenced, the data value stored in it is retrieved for use.

problems.name: Overview
problems.text:
Variables

Variables are storage locations in memory with symbolic names. These symbolic names are used in your program to specify where in memory to store data values, and which memory locations to retrieve data from.

  • The main mechanism for storing data into memory is the assignment statement
  • retrieving data from memory is done by expression evaluation

To complete this problem, type this variable declaration, with an initialization (assigning the first value to the variable): 
    var x = 5;
Then type this to do retrieval: 
    alert(x);
The variable name "x" here is a simple expression. Evaluating such as expression means going to the storage location for "x" in memory and retrieving the data value stored there. Since the alert statement evaluates the expression inside the parentheses, it retrieves the 5 that was stored in "x" when it was declared.

Run your program locally. You have declared (created) a variable "x", stored a value 5 into it, and then retrieved that value to print out. Now submit it for scoring.

Note: If you did as requested, you will see that you got no style points. The error message says 

    Style error: first line must be: "use strict";
Making this the first line of a JavaScript program tells the language processor to be sure you declare all variables you use. This means all variables like "x" must have a "var x" declarations someplace in the program. Good style is to put your declarations up top. We will cover this in more detail as we go along and get more complex language structure to work with.

So from here on (unless noted otherwise) make sure the first line of your program is this: 
  "use strict";
Add that line and try submitting again.

problems.name: Boolean "AND"ing
problems.text:
