Write a program that prints out the result of combining the boolean value true with the boolean value false using the AND operator (written &&). We often refer to this as "AND-ing two boolean expressions together".

When we combine two number values together using a number operation (like *), the result is a number. In the same way, the result of combining two boolean values together using a boolean operator (like &&) will be a boolean value. There are only 2 boolean values, so evaluating a boolean expression will produce either true or false. Which value we get depends on the rules for the operator being used. For AND, the result will only the true if both the operands are true. If one of the two operands is false (or both), the result will be false as well. A table that expresses these 4 possible combinations along with the result is called a truth table.

Given these rules, what do you expect your program to print when you evaluate the expression true && false ?

Here is the full truth table for the logical AND operator: 

   P        Q          P && Q
 ------   -------    ----------         logical AND (also called conjunction)
  true     true       true
  true     false      false
  false    true       false
  false    false      false

problems.name: DIY: Boolean "OR"ing
problems.text:
Write a program that prints out the result of combining the boolean value false with the boolean value true using the OR operator ( written || ).
We often refer to this as "OR-ing two boolean expressions together".

The rules for OR are these: the result will only be false if both the operands are false. If one of the two operands (or both) is true, the result will be true as well. Given these rules, what do you expect your program to print when you do false || true ?

Here is the full truth table for the logical OR operator: 

   P        Q          P || Q
 ------   -------    ----------         logical OR (also called disjunction)
  true     true       true
  true     false      true
  false    true       true
  false    false      false

problems.name: DIY: Fun with Distance, Time, and Speed
problems.text:
Write a program to solve the following word problem. Print out a single number (no text with it).

Word problem: A bicyclist travels 43.6 miles in 3 hour and 27 minutes. What was the average speed of the cyclist in feet per second?

To solve this we would need to compute the total number of feet traveled, and then divide that by the total number of seconds it took to travel that distance. Since we are practicing declaring and using variables, use at least 4 variables; there is no need to use more than 10.

problems.name: DIY: Final class grade
problems.text:
Write a program to compute and print the final course grade for a student, expressed as a number between 0 and 100.

The student's name is Future Coder, and the student has 4 assignment grades: 99.0, 87.5, 71.8, and 97.2. The student also has these two exam grades: 74.0 and 88.25. Assignments are worth 60% of the final grade, and exams are worth 40%.

Print the average grade using this output format: 

Future Coder has an average grade of 85.775
No blanks are ahead of the "Future" and no blanks follow the number. Since we are practicing declaring and using variables, have at least 3 and no more than 7.

problems.name: Counter: count loop body execs
problems.text:
Write a program that will count how many times a loop body executes. The parameters of the loop (start, stop, increment) will be constants (0, 25, 1).

Use a for loop, and run it from 0 to 25, including both 0 and 25. You will also need to create and use a "counter", a variable that has its value bumped up by 1 when some event happens that you wish to count. Since we are summing, the counter will be initialized to 0 (the additive identity) outside the loop.

In this case, the event we want to count is each time the loop body executes. To do this we will put the increment statement for the counter inside the loop body. When the loop is done, print out the count.

We have seen that the loop index variable acts as a counter of sorts. In this lesson we are learning that the general idea of a counter is useful in many contexts, and we can create a counter as needed with a variable that we increment at appropriate times or points during execution.

Style: Use one for loop and no other loops.

problems.name: Overview: input errors, and "return"
problems.text:
Overview: Input errors

Up to now we have asked the user for input and have assumed that the user provides values that correctly match what we want. However, we cannot in general write programs using this assumption. Users make errors. We need to write our programs to deal gracefully with such errors. At the very minimum we can detect input errors, notify the user, and end execution. We might also ask the user to do the input again, correctly and keep asking until the errors end. As we get more sophisticated we could even try to adapt the input values, correct them and use them in a new form.

There are many ways a user can give erroneous input, but for now we will deal with 3 major types:

  • type error: the user is asked to input a number but give something like "go heels", which is not a number
  • format error: the use is asked for an integer, but gives something like 24.713 which is not an integer
  • range error: the user is asked for a positive integer less than 50, but types in something like -5 or 101.
We will see how to check for each of these in the programs in this section. For now to complete this overview type this code in as the body of function myMain and run it locally (don't submit yet for scoring): 
  var x =5;
  alert(x);
  // return;
  var y=7;
  alert(y);
Note that the "return" statement is commented out initially. When we run this program we see two alert boxes pop up, the first with ouput "5" and the second with output "7.

Now remove the comment slashes before the "return" line. Now the return statement will execute. Run the code again. Now what you will see is that the code before the "return" executes, and the code after does not. So the output now is the single output "5" and then myMain stops executing at the return. We can use the "return" statement at any point in a function to make the function cease executing and go back to the part of the program where it was called.

Submit the altered code, with the return, for scoring.

problems.name: Array handling
problems.text:
Write a program that will sum up the elements in an array. Do it two ways: iteratively (with a loop), and recursively. For each way, print the sum.

We saw a task earlier (in the overview) that could be done with a loop or with recursion, both giving the same functional results. It turns out that any computation that can be done with recursion can be done with looping (and no recursion). Recursion is the functional way to do looping. This is largely a theoretical consideration, as there are still many times when looping is better to use (more efficient in time and memory use).

In this program we show another example of doing one computation both recursively and non-recursively. We also illustrate here the use of recursion in manipulating data structures (an array). We will write a program that processes an array of numbers two ways. First in myMain we will declare an array variable and initialize it with these 8 integers: 

  var nums = [10,20,30,40,50,60,70,80];

Next we will write an iterative function that will receive an array as a parameter. It will then sum up all the elements in the array and return that sum. The iterative function will get the work done with a for loop using a pattern we have done several times in other problems.

Next we write a recursive function to do the same computation. We will pass in an array, and return the sum of the elements in that array. The base case happens when the array that is passed in has no elements. We detect this case by looking at the length of the parameter array, and if that length is 0 we return 0 as the sum (no recursing needed). If the array has a length or 1 or larger, then the strategy for recursion is to "separate" the array into two pieces: the first element, and the array that is left when we take the parameter array and take off the first element. We can call our function recursively on this shortened array, and it will return the sum of the elements in the parameter array slots 1 on up. We then add the first element to that and get the sum of the entire array.

Finally write a myMain function that will first call the iterative function on the array, and then call the recursive function on the array. Print "looping" and then with a second alert, print the sum returned by the iterative function. Then print "recursion" and with another alert, print the sum given by the recursive function.

Computer science note. We have said one very important aspect of a recursive function is to make sure that the recursive case is given a smaller problem to work on (and that the smaller problem is shrinking down to a base case). In previous examples, the smaller problem meant passing a smaller number as parameter. Here we are passing a smaller array... an array that is shorter by one element. We are headed to the base case of a zero-length array.

problems.name: Canvas and basic drawing
DIY: Parameterize drawCircle
problems.text:
Start with the code we wrote in class for "Canvas and basic drawing. In that code we wrote a function called "drawCircle" that took no parameters. We also wrote a function called "drawRectangle" that did (eventually) get some parameters so we could call it repeatedly and make rectangles get drawn at different places around the canvas.

Write a version of "drawCircle" that is similarly parameterized.

problems.name: DIY: makePersonObject 2
problems.text:
Let's modify the previous program "array of objects". We will keep the same basic data and computed results, but we will change the structure of the two functions a bit. We are going to move the user input out of makePersonObject and relocate it to myMain. The values from the user will be passed to makePersonObject as arguments (4 arguments); then in makePersonObject the values of the arguments will be put into the fields when the object is manufactured. As before, makePersonObject will return the new object and in myMain that object will be put into an array.

Output should be the same as before. First, compute the total payroll. To do this, go through the array and sum up all the amounts paid to each worker. Print this out with this format: "total payroll: 1234.56"

Then go through the array and find the name of the person with the highest hourly pay rate. Print out the name in this format: "high rate: smith"

problems.name: W.Graphics (35 pts): Draw a Cards Picture
problems.text:
(30-5 pts) Due Sat. 12/5, 11:59 pm

You will write a program that will use HTML5 graphics to draw a picture of your card deck and hands.

See this detailed description.

TO GET SCORED
The auto-grader will score this a 0 for functionality and 0 for style. It will be manually graded like a previous brick we did (last one in Arrays and Random).

When you are done and wish to have it manually scored, please submit it via the "submit" button and then click the "share" button on the resulting submission. I will see the share request and consider that a request for scoring. I will score this assignment one time.

problems.name: CG: Hands as decks
problems.text:
Start with your code fro CG4. We are going to make a hand an object (right now it is simply as array of cards). Note that decks are arrays of cards with function that move the cards around. We should be able to make a hand a "deck" then. We will do with a new "addCard" function in the deck object. We will make the deal method create a new deck with 0 cards initially, and add in the proper number of cards into the hand from the deck.

This one is not scored. To see if your code is working do these things.
  1. Make a deck of 52 cards
  2. show the deck... see that the cards are there in order
  3. shuffle the deck
  4. show the shuffled deck
  5. deal a hand of 5 cards from the deck into a variable in myMain
  6. this hand variable is an object like the deck... so show the hand to see the first 5 cards that were in the deck
  7. show the deck again... to see the first 5 cards are gone
  8. shuffle the hand ! yes it is a "deck"
  9. show the hand again to see the cards in new order

problems.name: My First Program
problems.text:
Our goal here is just to experience running Bricks.
However, this will be your first program, and we will make it a classic.
Type this in the editor window: 

  alert ( "Hello world !!" ) ;

Once you have typed it, click on the "test locally" (orange) button. This makes your browser run your program and you will see any output from that program pop up on your screen. As you work on your programs you will use "test locally" to determine if your program is computing the proper requested outputs.

After running the program locally, click the "submit for score" (green) button. This will send your program to my server computer for scoring. We test your code against some test data to see if it produces correct output. We also look at the code to see if it adheres to good structure and style. We will discuss good style as the semester goes on.

After submitting the program you will receive feedback on how well it worked, and hopefully some points as well. You can submit your code as many times as you like (unless on occasion I indicate a limit to submissions... like for an exam). You will be given the highest score of all the submissions. So if you get the problem correct, and keep messing with the code and break the program, you will still get the full score on it.

This is intended to encourage you to make changes to your code and try different ways to get the answers computed. Feel free to experiment. Have some fun.

All your submissions are retained in our database and you can view them below the editor window. You can reload any submission back into the editor window in case you want to write a new program by building on a past one.

As the semester goes on, your submission can be used as well to ask for comments or assistance on a program, and to share your code with the instructor for display and discussion in class.

problems.name: Overview
problems.text:
Conditional Statements

A "conditional" statement, or a conditional, is the structure we use in a program to ask a question (a boolean comparison) and take some action, or another, based on the answer to the question. For example, we may request from the user a positive integer between 1 and 100. Once the user gives a number, we ask the question "is this number in the correct range?" and if the answer if "yes" we then compute some formula; however, if the answer is "no", we report an error and do NOT try to compute the formula.

Conditional statements allow us to direct the flow of control in a program; that is, they allow us to skip some blocks of code when appropriate, or to choose one of two blocks to execute, but not both. There are several forms of conditional. In this module we look at the most common ones: if-then, if-then-else, and a "cascade" of choices.

To complete this overview, type the following code into the editor (in myMain format), run it locally, then submit it for score: 

  var x = 5;
  if ( x > 0 )  { alert("x is positive");  }
  if ( x < 0 )  { alert("x is negative");  }
  if (x === 0)  { alert("x is zero");  }
Once you have done this for score, try running the code with different values assigned to x, and see the different outputs you get (run these trials locally only, do not submit for score). For example, if you replace the first line with 
  var x = -24;
Then your output should indicate that x is negative.

problems.name: Modulo ( % )
problems.text:
Write a program that prints the remainder when 26 is divided by 3 (integer division).

To do this, we will use the modulo operator (or mod operator) which is expressed with the " % " symbol. The mod operator can be thought of as the "remainder" operator. If we do division on numbers in JavaScript we get floating point (or real) arithmetic. With this division, we would expect the expression 

  26 / 3
to produce the floating point number 8.66666666, or 8 2/3 . In integer division (not something JavaScript does) we would say the result is 8, with 2 left over. So what we want for remainder in this problem is the 2 in the numerator of the 2/3 remainder. "Two left over".

In modular arithmetic (using the mod operator) the evaluation uses integer division and the results are expressed as an integer and a remainder. Thus we solve this problem this way: 
   26 % 3
The mod operator ( % ) is defined this way: a % b is the remainder when a is divided by b, using integer division. Here, the integer 3 goes into 26 completely 8 times, with 2 left over. Therefore, the expression produces the remainder 2. Once you have programmed the proper code for this problem, try other values to make sure you see how the % operator works. For example, try these: 
  5 % 12   // expect 5
 10 % 5    // expect 0
  5 % 5    // expect 0
 10 % 0    // expect error, divide by 0, Javascript gives Nan for "Not a Number"
 18 % 12   // clock face is mod 12... 18 oclock is really 6 oclock PM
Try some negative numbers as well.

One commonly understood example of modular arithmetic is the common clock face. As the hands go around over and over, we do not get 13 o'clock, then 25 o'clock, then 37 o'clock, etc as time goes by. Rather the "time" resets at 12 every revolution. So instead of 13 o'clock, we get 1 o'clock again.

problems.name: Concept Overview: The Great 8
problems.text:
In this problem we will give a broad overview of the concepts we will be learning over the modules of this course.

There are literally hundreds of programming languages in use today. Some date back to the late 50's and early 60's (like FORTRAN, COBOL and Lisp). Some are only a few years old (like Rust, Go, Clojure, and TypeScript). There are several major styles of programming but the one that we will be using here in this course, and the style that is predominant all over, is called imperative programming. In an imperative programming language, data values are stored in named locations in computer memory (called the program state) and programming language statements make changes to the program state.

We don't need to worry about the differences between imperative programming and other styles; that is for later courses. However, we do want to understand the major concepts that are in ALL imperative programming languages. There are seven: 

  1)  data and types of data
  2)  variables: saving data into memory for later use
  3)  expressions: retrieving data back from memory and combining data to make new values
  4)  repetition (looping)
  5)  decision making (conditional statements)
  6)  procedure abstraction (functions)
  7)  simple data abstraction (arrays)

There is also a very important concept 8 that is in most modern programming languages (imperative as well as other styles): 
  8) everything abstraction (objects)
Objects combine code and data in an abstraction that recapitulates a program itself. Programming languages with this 8th concept are called "object-oriented" languages, and they enable object-oriented programming.

We will call these concepts "The Great 8". As noted, all imperative programming languages have the first 7, and JavaScript has all 8. We will be studying and practicing them one at a time as we move through the lesson modules. The complexity of the programs we write will increase as we add each new concept to our repertoire.

To get credit for this overview, type this in the editor window: 

  alert ( "The Great 8" ) ;
Once you have typed it, click on the "test locally" (orange) button. Then submit it for scoring after you see it producing the proper output.

problems.name: PEMDAS: Operator precedence
problems.text:
Write a program that adds 5 to 10, and then multiplies the result by 3. Print out the result as a single number.

We have to be careful in this program to pay attention to the order in which the operations are done. It can affect the final value of the expression, and can give erroneous results if we are not careful.

You may have learned a memory trick in math class pertaining to order of operation evaluation. Remember PEMDAS? These are what we call operator precedence rules. The rules tell us which operators must precede which others during evaluation.

The rules are better written P-E-MD-AS I think, as there is no preference for M over D; likewise, no preference for A over S. According to PEMDAS, when we have an expression to evaluate, we first scan the expression left to right and do all the most deeply nested parentheses first as sub-expressions. Then we scan left to right and do exponentiation. Then we scan left to right and do all multiplication and division as we come to them. Finally, we scan left to right and do all addition and subtraction, as we come to them.

It pays to know PEMDAS, since JavaScript will evaluate expressions following those rules of operator precedence. But it also pays in clarity to use the P part heavily to make sure your expression is evaluated as you intend. Use parentheses to force the order you want. Any readers of your code will appreciate it, and you will make fewer mistakes.

problems.name: Complicated boolean expressions
problems.text:
Write a program that compares 3 quantities stored in variable x, y, and z. We want to know if the values are in numerical order, with x the smallest and z the largest (assume all 3 values are different).

Up to now our boolean comparisons have involved two operands. Let's look at how to construct more complex expressions that involve 3 (or more) operands.

Let's say we have 3 variables that contain numbers (the same approach shown here works for string data). We need to decide if all 3 values in those variables are different. We cannot simply string the 2-operand comparison together (like some math notation allows). It will be legal to do this in JavaScript, but the results will be confusing (as it does not do what you think it is doing... what it is really doing is beyond this level of class). All boolean comparisons involve 2 operands and 1 operator, like this 

val1  op  val2
for example 
12 < 15
x > y
k <  21
speed !== 100

If we have 3 variables (values) to compare we must make a collection of 2-value camparisons and use AND (&&) or OR ( || ) to glue them together in the way we need. Consider these: 

var x=4, y=5, z=6;
x < y < z            // incorrect way
(x < y) && (y < z)    // correct way
We must compare them pair-wise. To do this we will need to put parentheses around the pair comparisons to make sure the && has two operands. Each expression in parens (like ( x < y ) ) is an expression just like x by itself is an expression.

To complete this problem type in this program and execute it... see if the results are what you expect. 

"use strict";

function myMain() {
  var x = 3;
  var y = 4;
  var z = 6;

  var expn = ( x < y ) && (y < z) ;
  alert(expn);
}

myMain();
Try changing the values of x, y, and z so you can see how different values cause different comparison results.

Notes: If you want a bit more explanation, then consider this. What does it mean to try to do something like alert( 4 < 5 < 6 )? You may have noticed JavaScript allows this and produces output. In fact, if you try this very experssion you get "true" as output... and this may be leading to some confusion. What JavaScript is doing is systematic... all comparison expressions are two operands and one operator, so JavaScript is doing this: 

alert(  ( 4 < 5 ) < 6 );
// which simplifies to  alert( true < 6 );
And now we are left wondering... what does it mean is "true" smaller than 6 ? The way this is handled is beyond what we need to do at this point, but JavaScript does find a way to determine this as "true". However to see how confusing this can be try this: 
alert(  4 < 5 < 2 );
// which becomes alert(  ( 4 < 5 ) < 2 );
// which becomes  alert(  true < 2 );
Now we also get true, so this violates our math-ish idea of what we want with 4 < 5 < 2. This shows that this way of doing things is not what we want for our boolean comparisons. So do them the way of this lesson... 2 at a time, using parentheses for clarity.

problems.name: DIY: Construct car objects
problems.text:
Write a program that makes 3 car objects, and then prints out the make, model, and year of the oldest of the 3 cars (format shown below).

We are going to build this program from the code for problem "Car object" earlier in this module. Reload that working program and let's modify it. First, make myMain be a car object constructor. To do this, rename the myMain to "makeCarObject" and then remove the alert statement -- we will not do any output inside the object constructor (it will do input prompts). To complete the constructor, put in a return statement that sends back the car object that gets constructed.

Next we need a new myMain function. In this myMain, we will call the constructor makeCarObject 3 times, and save the returned object each time in a different variable. Next we need to decide which car object represents the oldest car. This would be the one with the smallest number in the year field of the object. Then we use the fields of that object to produce the final output.

For output, we will use one alert statement. In that alert, print the make, model, and year of the oldest car, and put a ", " (comma then space) between values. For a red ford ranger built in 1997, it would look like this: 

ford, ranger, 1997

Development Notes: Other than practicing the object syntax and constructor concept we learned, the challenge in this program is to figure out which object is the oldest car, in such a way that we can access the object after we figure that. One way to do this is to note that if I have 3 different objects stored in 3 variables (let's say named car1, car2, and car3), then this is a valid JavaScript statement: 

var oldest = car1;
What we do here is create another variable ("oldest") and make the value of that new variable the same object as the one stored in "car1". This is the same as doing something like this with number data: 
var x = 5;
var y = x;
// at this point we expect y to contain the value 5
Then test the other car objects to see if any has a year smaller than the year of the one you have stored in "oldest". Since variable oldest has a car object in it, this is valid JavaScript: 
if (car2.year < oldest.year) { 
   // then save car2 in oldest... you have discovered that car2 is older that the one you started with,
   // so car2 is now currently your oldest
}

problems.name: Overview
problems.text:
Searching: A big problem

Sorting and Searching are two large important categories of problems in Computing Science. You use them all the time in the software you use daily. Go to eBay, for example, and try to find and buy something you have in mind. You first search for it (find all blue UNC coffee mugs) and then the sort the output (put them in order of lowest price to highest). Sorting is for later (and perhaps a later class).

Searching is first. Searching is the process of examining the data elements in a collection (arrays here) to see which elements match some criterion, or meet some requirement we have for the needs of some computation. "Find all elements in an array that are prime numbers", or "Find the first element in an array that is negative", or "check the elements in this array to see if they are all in alphabetic order", or "does this array of names contain someone named "Jane Doe". These are examples of searches.

We will be learning in this module how to systematically go through an array, looking at every element slot-by-slot and comparing them to each other or to some value we are trying to match. Most of the searching we do in arrays will use for-loops. This is because the array lengths are known and are convenient as loop control parameters. Type in the following code to search in an array: 

"use strict";

function myMain() {
  var arr = [3,11,438,-21,895,67,1101,19,4.3,-6];
  for (var i=0; i < arr.length; i++) {
    if ((arr[i]%3)===0) { 
      alert(arr[i] + ": multiple of 3"); 
    }
  }
}

myMain();
Here, the for loop allows us to examine the array slots in order, starting at 0 and going to the last slot in use. Each time we do the loop body we examine the slot number that the loop index variable "i" contains as value. We are looking for multiples of 3, and if we find an array element that is one, we print out that value.

problems.name: Overview
problems.text:
Functions are first-class values

Functions in JavaScript are what we call "first class values". This means a function is a "value" of some type (type "function") just as 5 is a value of type number. First class values can be assigned to variables. We are already familiar with this using number (or string) data. Consider this code: 

  var x = 8;
  var y;
  y = x;
  alert(x);
  alert(y);
We exect that 8 will get printed by each alert statement. By assigning 8 to x, and then by assigning the contents of x to y, we expect that the variable "y" is, in essence, a name for the value 8 just as "x" is a name for the value 8. The value 8 is the same, no matter which name (variable) we use to denote the value. Either way, using either variable, we get the number value 8, the same value that we get when we double the number value 4. There is only one number value 8, but we may denote it many different ways.

Now consider this code: 

"use strict";

function myMain ( ) {
   alert( double(5) );
}

function double ( n ) {  return 2*n; }

myMain();
In this program we define a function "double" that takes one argument. When called, function "double" multiplies its argument by 2 and returns that value. We have defined using the "function" keyword that we are accustomed to using for function definitions. Function "myMain" calls "double" on the number value 4 and alerts the returned result.

Now let's add some code to myMain: 

"use strict";

function myMain ( ) {
  var dubble;
  dubble = double; // assigns the function value bound to "double" to the name "dubble"
  alert( double(5) );  // note by color that "double" is a global name
  alert( dubble(5) );  // note by color that "dubble" is a local name inside myMain
}

function double ( n ) {  return 2*n; }

myMain();
This shows one function (the code that multiplies its argument by 2) with two different names ("double", and "dubble"). We can make that function code execute by calling it with the "double" name, or with the "dubble" name; we do both in this program.

This is the same thing we did before with a number value, except we have now done it with a function value. The function value is the code that constitutes the definition, and that is executed when the function runs. We say that the names "double" and "dubble" are bound to the function value. One way to bind a name to a function value is with the "function keyword". Now we see that another way is to take the function value that one name denotes and bind it to another name via assignment.

Since the function "double" is declared at the global level, the name "double" is visible inside myMain, and can be used inside myMain. If "double" were not visible inside myMain we could not call the function. Since it is visible, we can not only call it to make it execute, but we can assign it to some other variable. Then we have two "names" for the one function value (the function that multiplies its single argument by 2 and returns that value). The function value is not the name -- it is the code.

To get credit for this overview, put the last code (with "double" and "dubble") in your editor window and submit it for scoring.

problems.name: Overview
problems.text:
Recursion: Functions that call themselves

Recursion is a very useful programming technique in which a function calls itself (re-cursion means re-occurring) in order to get a solution to a smaller or simpler version of the problem that it is trying to solve. For some problems, recursive code is simpler than equivalent code that is non-recursive -- easier to write, and more compact and less complex. But the concept can be confusing, especially when first learning programming. We will just get a taste of it in this module without going into in in deep detail.

The key to recursion is to make sure when the function calls itself, the problem that is passed to that call is a smaller or simpler version. We think of a recursive function as saying "well now, if I let some function solve a smaller or simpler version of my problem, then I know how to use that smaller solution to solve my bigger problem."

Every recursive function will have two main parts:

  • the base case
  • the recursive call
We will write the base case first, and the base case will not recurse (will not call the function again). The base case is the simplest verion of the problem, where the result is known and can be returned directly. The base case will usually be a test to see if the parameter is some smallest value. The base case is very important. Leaving it out can make your recursive function run forever when it is called. The base case is the trigger that ends the sequence of function calls that is a recursion.

If the base case does not apply, then we enter the recursive case, where the function calls itself, captures the return value, and then uses that simpler return value to construct a solution it can return for it's own execution. Examples will make all this much easier to visualize.

Put this code in your editor window and run it: 

"use strict";

function myMain ( ) {
  var N = 5;
  alert("iteration ...");
  sequenceIter( N );
}

function sequenceIter ( n ) {
  for (var i=n; i>=0; i--) {
    alert(i);
  }
}

myMain();
When you run this locally you will see it generates a sequence of numbers as output: 5,4,3,2,1,0. Do not submit it for score yet.

Now put this code in your editor window and execute it: 

"use strict";

function myMain ( ) {
  var N = 5;
  alert("iteration ...");
  sequenceIter( N );
  alert("recursion ...");
  sequenceRecur( N );
}

function sequenceRecur( n ) {
  alert(n);
  if (n===0) { return; }     // base case
  sequenceRecur(n-1);   // recursive case
}

function sequenceIter ( n ) {
  for (var i=n; i>=0; i--) {
    alert(i);
  }
}

myMain();
This code now generated the sequence with both iteration, and with a recursive function ("sequenceRecur"). You see both functions do the same thing... one using looping and no further function calls, and one using recursion.

problems.name: DNA Sequence Analysis
problems.text:
Write a program that searches for occurrences of base pairs in a DNA sequence. First ask the user to input a DNA sequence (as a string). Then loop, asking the user for a base pair (as a string of 2 characters) and print the number of times that base pair occurs in the DNA sequence (using the output format below). Details follow.

A DNA sequence representation is a string composed entirely of the capital letter "A", "C", "T", and "G". For example, each of the following lines represents a DNA sequence: 

ACATGAGACAGACAGACCCCCAGAGACAGACCCCTAGACACAGAGAGAG
TATGCAGGACAGGGTTTTTGCCCAGGGTGGCAGTATG
AGGATTGAGGTATGGGTATGTTCCCGATTGAGTAGCCAGTATGAGCCAG
AGTTTTTTACAAGTATTTTTCCCAGTAGCCAGAGAGAGAGTCACCCAGT
The following are sample executions: 
What DNA sequence? ACATCCTGAGACAGACAGACCCCCAGA
What base pair?  CA
The base pair 'CA' occurs 4 times in the DNA sequence 'ACATCCTGAGACAGACAGACCCCCAGA'
What base pair? TG
Base pair 'TG' occurs 1 times in DNA sequence 'ACATCCTGAGACAGACAGACCCCCAGA'
What base pair? CC
Base pair 'CC' occurs 5 times in DNA sequence 'ACATCCTGAGACAGACAGACCCCCAGA'
What base pair? done

Note how we are counting occurrences. In this string 
CCCC
we are saying that "CC" occurs 3 times (not 2). We do not count the first two characters as a match, and then move on to the 3rd character. Rather we start with the first "C and notice that there is a "C" following it, for the first match. We move on to the 2nd character, which is a "C" and we note a "C" following it (for the 2nd match). We move on to the 3rd character, which is a "C", and we note a "C" following it (for the 3rd match). I am not sure if this is how biologists count these things, but that is how we will do it here for this program. We call it a "sliding window" that is sliding one character at a time. For fun, you can try writing your own program where the string "CCCC" would produce 2 matches... a sliding window that slides to the end of any match it finds to keep going.

String functions: There are a couple string functions you may find useful. First, the function " split " will take a string and produce (return) an array of individual characters, one character from the string stored in each slot location in the array. A string value in JavaScript is an object, and "split" is a method that can be called on the object. For example consider this code: 

var str = "go heels!";
chars = str.split("");
alert(chars[0]);  // will print "g"
alert(chars[1]);  // will print "o"
alert(chars[2]);  // will print " "  a blank character
alert(chars[3]);  // will print "h"
alert(chars[str.length - 1]);   // will print "!"
Here, using the parameter "" in the call to the split method causes the string to be burst apart into individual characters. The split method can be used to split strings into other chunks based on other characters; google it up for more information.

Another possibly useful string method is " charAt ". This string method will produce (return) a single character, the one found at a specific position in the string. Character positions in a string start at 0 and go up to one less than the length of the string. For example consider this code: 

 var bp = "AG" ;
 var first = bp.charAt(0);
 var second = bp.charAt(1);
 var last = bp.charAt(bp.length - 1);
 alert(first);    // prints "A"
 alert(second);  // prints "G"
 alert(last);    // prints "G"

Other challenges: As further practice, you can alter how searching is done and try coding different versions of this program (for practice, not for score). For example, only count a base pair if it occurs within 10 (or 20, or some limit) characters of some other base pair. Or dont count a base pair if it immediately follows an occurrence of itself. Or count base pair pairs... if the base pair is AT for example, then look for ATAT and count that. Make up your own search pattern and code it up.

problems.name: Mortgage calculator
problems.text:
Write a program that will compute mortgage information. Ask the user to input an total amount borrowed (real number, dollars), an interest rate (a real number between 0.0 and 100.0), a repayment time frame (in months, an integer), and an amount extra to pay each month (real number, dollars). Print the total number of payments that will be made over the life of the loan (the extra amount will make it smaller than the repayment number of months). Details follow.

Sample executions: 

Amount borrowed? 150000.00                    // prompt
Interest rate? 3.5                            // prompt
Number of months?  360                        // prompt
Extra principle paid each month?  1000.00     // prompt
Total number of payments: 247                 // alert

Using the user inputs amount, rate, and months figure the monthly payment that will make the payoff happen. The print that monthly payment. Then ask the user to input a dollar amount that will be paid each month as additional principle. Let's call that extra. This means each month, the user will pay payment+extra dollars towards the loan. The interest will be charged on the remaining balance as simple interest... meaning is 3% is the rate, then each month the borrower pays 3/12 %, or 0.25 of the remaining balance. Using this, figure how many payments (months) it will take to knock the balance down to 0 and pay off the loan.

problems.name: Bletchley Park and Enigma
problems.text:
Write a program that will compute the Enigma cipher, similar to the ones produced by the Enigma machines in WW2. Details follow.

Bletchley Park is an easy drive northwest of London. In World War II the mansion housed the Government Code and Cypher Schools and was the main location for British intelligence codebreakers. The men and women working there regularly penetrated the secret communications of the Axis Powers most importantly the German Enigma and Lorenz ciphers. The intelligence gathered at Bletchley was termed "Ultra" and historians general consider the work to have shortened the war by two to four years. Without it, the outcome of the war would have been uncertain.

The Enigma cipher was a German code used before and during WW2. It was largely considered unbreakable (in pre-computer days) but that was not so. Polish mathematicians learned how early forms of the code worked, but breaking it became impractical at the outbreak of WW2 as the Germans added complexity to the basic machines, and changes keys daily. Due to the huge number of combinations used in how the characters were transposed during encoding, decoding rapidly was nearly impossible. Alan Turing, working at Bletchley in Britain, created a machine (the Bombe) that was able to reduce the possible combinations down to a number where crypt-analysts were able to decipher coded messages. Breaking the Enigma code enabled the British to gather very important intelligence that is often credited with tipping the war in favor of the Allied forces and shortening it by several years. The historical significance is hard to underestimate.

We are going to write a program that will encode, and decode, messages using the Enigma cipher.

Sample executions: 

BLAH

problems.name: Overview
problems.text:
Parsing: Decomposing text strings

In this module we will learn a little about "parsing", which is breaking up text strings into pieces... into a collection of smaller strings, or components. Parsing is part of many computing applications. For example, in order to execute your JavaScript program, a compiler or interpreter must take the single text string that is your program and find all the important substring pieces... components like the keywords "function" and "true" and "while"... variable names, and number constants... all parts within the one long program string. We will see how to do a simple form of this using some JavaScript built-in string functions.

The string type in JavaScript has some built-in methods (functions) that you can ask any string to execute. The one we will use to parse is the "split" function. You should google "JavaScript string split" and read the details. It takes a parameter, which is a single character; and it returns an array of strings. The split functions will break the string that executes it into parts using the character that is sent as parameter to define the boundaries between parts; the parts will be placed into successive locations in the array that is returned. For example, consider this code: 

var long = "alpha beta gamma";
var parts= long.split(" ");
The second line causes the string "long" to be divided into 3 substrings using the blank as the separator. This means the array "parts" has "alpha" in parts[0], "beta" in parts[1]. and "gamma" stored in parts[2]. Try this code, and alert elements from the array "parts" to see how split works.

The split function can divide a string using any character as the break point, not just a blank. For example, if you want to get a string of data (from a database, perhaps) and it consists of several numbers separates by commas, you can break the data string down this way: 

var data = "123,24.571,15,-37.2,0.01" ;
var nums = data.split(",");
alert(nums[0]);
alert(nums[3]);
If you try this code, you will see the numbers "123" and "-37" printed out in separate alert boxes. Note that the elements in the array "nums" are still strings (that look like numbers). If you need real numeric data you still need to convert the string data to number data (with the Number() function). To see this, run the code above and add these lines at the end: 
alert(nums[0]+nums[1]);  // string concatenation
alert(Number(nums[0]) + Number(nums[1]));  // numerical arithmetic

To complete this overview, type in the following program, execute it, then submit it for score. 

"use strict";

function myMain() {
  var text = "see how parsing breaks up strings";
  var arr = text.split(" ");
  alert(arr[2]);
  alert(arr[3]);
  alert(arr[arr.length-1]);
}

myMain();

problems.text:

problems.text:
Methods: Functions inside objects

Objects are the capstone item in the list of the Great 8 concepts we find in all object-oriented programming languages. Up to now, we have seen that an object is a way of binding data values ("fields") together so that they remain associated for a common purpose... such as representing different pieces of information about a person (name, age, address, pay rate, hours worked, etc.). Now we will see that functions can also be fields in an object. We call a function inside an object a "method" of that object.

Thus, an object binds together data fields, and functions (methods) that operate on those data fields. This makes an object an abstraction of a program in general. We can think of our "programs" as collections of objects that call each others' methods in order to get work done.

The methods inside an object will allow us to think of an object as being able to do work for us. In previous programs, we had an object constructor "makePersonObject" that would create an object that represented a worker at a company. The object had a field that told how many hours that person worked, and a field that told the pay rate the person earned per hour. To compute the amount of pay the person earned, we directly accessed the hours field and the payrate field in the object, retrieved their values, and multiplied those values together. We did this in the problem "Construct person object" in module "Basic Objects" if you would like to refer back to the code.

Now, we will be able to add a method (function) to the person object so that the person object can do that computation internally, where the hours and payrate fields are kept (we will do this in one of the following problems). We can then have a person object do that work for us, and simply report the total pay in response to our code elsewhere calling a function (a method) in the object. In essence, we will contact the object and get it to do what we were doing in our code before, but now we do not have to remember the details of what the internal data fields are named. We let the object worry about that in the "pay" function, and we simple call that function and wait for the results. We will not look inside the object at its data fields. The syntax for this will be: 
  var persObj = makePersonObject();
  var totalPay = personObj.pay();

To do this, we will alter the "makePersonObject" constructor to add the method to each objects it creates. Let's name that method "pay". This method takes no arguments, and when called, it returns the total pay earned by the person the object represents. This is computed by multiplying the person's pay rate by the person's hours worked.

To get credit for this overview: Let's take the "makePersonObject" code we had before and alter to put a very simple function into each object it makes. This function will report back the name of the person when it is called. Here is the new constructor code (and a myMain to exercise the constructor): 

"use strict";

function myMain () {
  var emp = makePersonObject();  // this makes a person object "emp"
  alert( emp.getName() ); // this is a method call on the object "emp"
}

function makePersonObject ( ) {
  var perObj = {
    id: Number(prompt("person ID number?")),
    name: prompt("person name?"),
    hours: Number(prompt("hours worked?")),
    payrate: Number(prompt("pay rate?")),

    // this is how we put a function into an object
    // we make an anonymous function and bind it to a field name
    getName: function ( ) { return this.name; } 

  };
  return perObj;
}

myMain();
Here we create a person object in myMain, and then call the "getName" in that object. We then print out the string returned by that method. In this way, the object is "telling us" the name it contains. Put this code in your editor window, test it locally, and then submit it for score.

Software Engineering lesson. Not looking inside an object at its data fields... letting the object itself worry about manipulating the data fields... getting information from an object by calling methods and letting the object send us data... this is called "information hiding". We think of an object as being a "black box" and we don't see it internals. We do see it's public interface... it's methods and how to call them (the arguments the methods need when called). If we want information, we ask the object to supply it rather that reaching inside and taking it. In this way, complicated manipulations can be written once and put into the object as methods. This is an example of the DRY principle at work. We do not repeat complicated manipulations of object data fields all over our code; rather we put them into the objects, as methods, each defined once. Then we call the functions when we need the information,

Some programming disciplines go as far as making data field invisible.. unable to be read outside the object. Then to get something simple (like the value of the name field in our person object) we would put a method like "getName()" in the person object. Maybe we put in a "setName(s)" method as well, in case we need to change the name stored in the object. We would not be allowed to do something direct like persObj.name = "Smith" from outside the object. Information hiding helps keep the data in the object consistent, since it cannot be changed by any code that it not a methods in the object.

These simple methods that produce, or update, the values of the data fields are called "getters" and "setters". The "getName()" methods we wrote in this overview code is an example of a "getter" method.

problems.name: Array of objects
problems.text:
Write a program that will generate several objects (using a constructor function) and store those objects in an array for later use.

We will start with the code from "Construct person object" from the "Basic Objects" folder. This gives us the myMain function as well as a constructor function "makePersonObject" that manufactures and returns objects after populating them with user input.

In myMain before we created 3 separate variables to store 3 objects. This means the code works for exactly 3 persons, and if the user has more (or fewer) to work with, then the code must be re-written (a little bit) to alter the number (and names) of the variables used to store the person objects.

In this new program we will make a loop and keep constructing objects until the user says we are done. Each new object made and returned by the constructor will be stored in an array slot (in much the same way we created and used an array to store number input from the user in other programs). In the loop, first call makePersonObject to manufacture a person object; store the object that is returned in the next open array slot. Then ask the user if another object needs to be made. If the reply is "no" then we will break to end the input loop. Any other reply will cause the loop to repeat and make another object.

Once the input loop is done and the array if filled with objects, we will use the objects to compute some information. First, print the length of the array (which is the number of objects stored in the array). Next, compute the total payroll. To do this, go through the array and sum up all the amounts paid to each worker. Print this out with this format: "total payroll: 1234.56"

Then go through the array and find the name of the person with the highest hourly pay rate. Print out the name in this format: "high rate: smith".

problems.name: Method (function) in an object
problems.text:
Write a program that illustrates putting a method into an object and calls that method.

Let's start with the code from "Array of objects".

Add a method to "makePersonObject" called "pay". This method takes no arguments, and returns the total pay earned by the person. This is computed by multiplying the person's pay rate by the person's hours worked.

In myMain, adjust your code to call this "pay" method instead of using the individual data fields in the person object. This program should print the same output as the one we stated with. Tests it, and submit for score.

Getter methods. Now we are going to alter the object constructor more. Finding the person with the highest pay rate was done before by reading the "name" and "payrate" fields in the person object directly. We will increase the information hiding in this program by adding two more methods to the person object, both "getter" methods. We will add "getName", a methods that will return the string stored in the "name" field. We will also add "getRate", a method that will return the number stored in the "payrate" field. After adding these getter methods we will alter the code in myMain to use them rather than reading the object fields directly.

Once all this is done, test the new code and then submit it for score. You will see that the functional behavior is the same.

problems.name: Silent constructor
problems.text:
Write a program that uses a "silent constructor" to build objects, and uses those objects.

In this program we will modify a previous one (Method in an object). In this program, we have a constructor for objects that model (represent) people. In the object constructor, interact with the user to get various pieces of data to put into the new object... data value like a name, an id, etc. Now we want to move the user interaction out of the constructor, and have that interaction done elsewhere in the program (like in myMain). This makes the constructor "slient" meaning it does not communicate with the user. Rather, the information needed by the constructor will be passed in as arguments when the constructor is called to make an object.

The code changes we need to make are detailed, so just follow along in order

Keep the constructor makePersonObject. In myMain clear out almost all the code, leaving a single call to makePersonObject to make one person object. Move the user input code from the constructor into myMain (before the call to the constructor). The values input will need to be stored in local variables in myMain, and then those variables will be passed in to the constructor as parameters.

In makePersonObject we will need to create an argument list in the definition header, and we will need to assign the passed argument values to the appropriate object fields. Test to make sure it is functioning as expected.

Finally, back in myMain, simply call the pay method on the object that the constructor returns, and print out the value that method returns.

problems.name: This vs. constructor local
problems.text:
Write a program that better illustrates the purpose of the "this" keyword in object methods, and illustrates the difference between object-creation time (when a constructor is called) and object-use time (when an object method is called).

In this program we will modify a previous one (Silent constructor). Load that code into the editor window.

The instructional point is to make clear the reason to use the "this" reference in an object, as well as to clarify the distinctions between a method (function) and a data field. The "this" object reference gives dynamic capabilities, allowing an object to compute information from what happens to be stored in the object fields at the time of method call. Referencing variables and parameters in the object constructor when the object is made will capture values that are static... maintain the values that existed at the time of object creation and will not change dynamically.

The code changes we need to make are detailed, so just follow along in order

In function makePersonObject let's now make a few more changes. First, rename the "pay" function to be called "payFunc". Let's also add a new field called "payData" that simple takes the hours and payrate parameters and multiplies them (not using the "this" object reference).

In myMain take the single person object that the constructor return, and alert the payData field. Then alert a call to the payFunc method. Run the program and see that both outputs are the same.

Now, after those alerts in myMain, add a line that doubles the hours field in the person object ( something like emp.hours *= 2; ). We have just doubled the hours that person worked, and we should see a doubling in the total pay. Repeat the two different alerts and see what happens.

The reason we now see a difference is because the payFunc method computes using whatever happens to be stored in the rate and hours fields at the time the method is called (the "this" keyword says to use the fields dynamically). So if we change the values stored in those fields during computation, the result returned by the methods call will change accordingly. However, the payData field is static; it's value is created and stored when the object is made, using values from local variables (parameters) in the constructor memory map. Those values are fixed at construction time and do not change as computation progresses.

problems.name: Canvas and basic drawing
problems.text:
Write a program that will draw some very basic figures on a web page. Use HTML 5 graphics to do this. Details follow.

We will write a program that will use the graphics features in HTML5 to make a simple drawing. HTML5 has a canvas tag that will set apart a rectangular space on a page.

Cut and paste the following JavaScript right after the "use strict"; line in your program: 


//=== supplied canvas stuff ==================================================
var tab = window.open();
var webPage = makeHTMLCanvas();  // alert(webPage);
var PIC = getCanvasContext();    // the canvas context... draw to this global var

function makeHTMLCanvas() {
  var htmlStr="";
  htmlStr += "<html><head></head><body>";
  htmlStr += "<h1>Draw a Picture!!</h1>";
  htmlStr += "<canvas id='myCanvas' width=800 height=600 ";
  htmlStr += "style='border:1px solid #000600;'></canvas>";
  htmlStr += "</body></html>";
  tab.document.write(htmlStr);
  return htmlStr;
}

function getCanvasContext() {
  var c = tab.document.getElementById("myCanvas");
  var context = c.getContext("2d");
  return context;
}

//=== end supplied canvas stuff ==================================================

After this pre-supplied code, then write the code for your program.

You may find this HTML5 Canvas tutorial helpful.

problems.name: DIY: Parameterize drawCircle
problems.text:
Write a program that will draw ... Use HTML 5 graphics to do this. Details follow.

Start with the code we wrote in class for "Canvas and basic drawing. In that code we wrote a function called "drawCircle" that took no parameters. We also wrote a function called "drawRectangle" that did (eventually) get some parameters so we could call it repeatedly and make rectangles get drawn at different places around the canvas.

Write a version of "drawCircle" that is similarly parameterized.

problems.name: DIY: Function drawTriangle
problems.text:
Write a program that will draw ... Use HTML 5 graphics to do this. Details follow.

Write a function "drawTriangle" that will draw a triangle on the canvas. Make it parameterized like drawRectangle so that we can repeatedly call drawTriangle and put triangles of different sizes at different places around the canvas.

To do this you will need to investigate how to draw lines on the canvas.

problems.name: { EC: RANDOM ARRAY 3 COPY }
problems.text:
To get scored: This one has to be manually scored.

I have set the grader to score it at 0 for functionality. You can receive some style points for the various aspects requested (functions written, no globals, myMain format etc.). I will then manually award the rest of the style points and the functionality points by examining and running your code. When you have tested the code and are ready for it to be scored, submit it and then click "share" on it so I will see that you wish me to take a look. I will only grade it once manually, so be sure you have tested it well before sharing it.

The program
Write a program that will create an array and put into it some integers randomly generated between 10 and 30 (including possibly each end point), making sure that all the numbers in the array are unique (no duplicates). The size of the array will be given by the user as the first thing; you will validate (see below). Once the array is properly filled, print the entire array with one alert statement.

This is a more complicated program than most previous bricks. Here are some specifics:
  • First, you will be validating the user input
  • Next, you must make sure each new integer you store in the array is unique -- that is, make sure it is not already in the array before you store it.
  • Also, you must write 5 functions here... myMain, getGoodInput(), genRandomInt(low,hi), alreadyIn ( n, arr ), and genUniqueIntArray ( n, hi, lo )
Function details

getGoodInput() For this function you will use the re-ask-the-user strategy; call this function and have all user interaction (prompts) inside it. Ask the user for an integer that is between 1 and 20 (inclusive), and make sure you get one; if the user gives anything else (meaning a string, a non-integer, a value smaller than 1 or larger than 20) print "error" and re-ask for input.

genRandomInt ( low, hi ) For this function, call Math.random inside it and then adjust tvalue so that the integer returned lies within the range lo to hi... inclusive of each. You did this in an earlier brick, so go back and find that code. Test it carefully to make sure it will be able to generate both lo and hi, and nothing outside that range.

alreadyIn ( n, arr ) For this function you check to see if parameter value "n" is in the array "arr". If it is, return a true; if it is not, return a false; You will call this function after you generate a new random integer to see if the number should be added to your array or not.

genUniqueIntArray ( n, lo, hi ) For this function you will create and return an array with unique random integers in it, each integer between lo and hi (inclusive). This function will call genRandomInt and will also call alreadyIn to decide if the new random integer is already in the array being built. If it is there, simple call genRandomInt again.. and again if necessary... until the number you get back is not in the array. At that point you add it to the array and keep going until the array is full. Once the array if filled, return the array.

myMain The myMain code is fairly simple. First, call getGoodInput to ifind out from the user how many integers to generate into the array. Then call genUniqueIntArray and pass it the user's array size number, as well as the range (30 hi, 10 low). Capture the array that is returned and save it in a variable. Then print out the entire array in one alert statement.

problems.name: W.GRAPHICS (35 PTS): DRAW A CARDS PICTURE
problems.text:
Write a program that will draw ... bigger. Use HTML 5 graphics to do this. Details follow.

(30-5 pts) Due Sat. 12/5, 11:59 pm

You will write a program that will use HTML5 graphics to draw a picture of your card deck and hands.

See this detailed description.

TO GET SCORED
The auto-grader will score this a 0 for functionality and 0 for style. It will be manually graded like a previous brick we did (last one in Arrays and Random).

When you are done and wish to have it manually scored, please submit it via the "submit" button and then click the "share" button on the resulting submission. I will see the share request and consider that a request for scoring. I will score this assignment one time.
